content.content: JustinCase Key Info Delegate Address: 0xCdB792c14391F7115Ba77A7Cd27f724fC9eA2091 Forum: @JustinCase Discord: @JustinCase#2274 Email: [email protected] Reddit: DAIJustinCase Your Delegate Video: Meet Your Delegate | Ep. 7 Ft. JustinCase - YouTube Resides in the UTC+1 time zone. Core Values Maintaining obligations – Trust comes from honouring commitments; trust is essential for adoption and use of the protocol. Growing the profitability of the protocol – Growth is good, but growth must lead to profitability. I favour increasing revenue over reducing costs. Simplicity – given a choice between a complex and a less complex solution I will favour the less complex one. Delegate Statement Summary: I will work towards:  Ensuring that a portion of the protocol profits are going towards maintaining a steady burn but recognize that the protocol has other strategic goals as well. Making sure that previously made deals are honoured and that changes, and terminations of deals are communicated well in advance. Enhancing growth of the protocol and adoption in new areas, while growing revenue and profitability. Communicating in a more easily understandable fashion and to try to create enthusiasm for governance among smaller holders of MKR.  Here are examples of me advocating some of these issues, A B C When I first got into Maker in the fall of 2018 the way it was presented to me was something like this: “This new protocol generates a stablecoin that it lends out and it uses the profits to burn the token and increase its value”. With a lifelong interest in finance and just dipping my toes into crypto, this was a sentence that resonated with me. It presented something different in the cryptosphere. I believe many others have heard a similar pitch and has for a time been somewhat disappointed that a combination of factors has led to long periods of no burn. As examples I have these two quotes from two different articles about Maker: “…All accrued fees on MakerDAO are paid in MKR. The protocol purchases MKR off the secondary market and burns it, ensuring proper alignment incentive between MKR token holders. The burning of MKR reduces its supply in circulation through its intentional destruction. It is an effective method for increasing and stabilizing the price of MKR with the increased value given to the holder resembling that of a dividend…” Link “…Token Burn “Burnt tokens” have effectively been destroyed, ultimately reducing the total supply of tokens in circulation. Interest accumulated on Maker vaults is paid back in Dai, this Dai is then automatically swapped for MKR and burned. This is the primary economic driver behind the price of MKR tokens. Burning MKR reduces the supply of tokens, putting constant upwards pressure on the price. The more Dai in circulation, the more interest is generated, the stronger the upwards pressure on MKR’s price …” Link This shows that the perception from the outside is that MKR tokens will be burned. Failing to live up to this expectation is to me a failure to meet obligations. I believe that prolonged periods with no burn is damaging to MakerDAO’s credibility and trust and has caused some retail investors to look to other projects, reducing value for remaining MKR holders. In order to maintain a healthy burn we must turn a healthy profit as well as keep the protocol safe and stable. As indicated by the portion of MKR in my portfolio I am a believer in the growth potential of Maker. I think there is a potential for capturing a larger market share in the cryptosphere, but I believe there is an even larger potential for growth in Real World Assets (RWA). Maintaining a burn touches into a broader issue of meeting obligations in general. As we grow larger in RWA, we’re going to have many entities depending on MakerDAO acting in good faith and honouring its obligations. Erratic behaviour will result in us losing trust with other entities and reducing our potential as a partner. My default stance will always be to maintain previous deals, either implicit or explicit. Strong arguments can sway a particular issue or stance but if we need to break off on a previous agreement it will have to be after giving a fair warning ahead of time that we intend to do so, assuming it is not possible to come to a mutually agreeable alternate plan. I recognize that Maker can have a very high barrier of entry and I will do my very best to try to keep my communication as understandable as possible with as little technical jargon and abbreviations as possible. Lastly, I’d like to share a little of my background. I’m currently working in business administration with a decade of experience. I hold an MBA with a major in Strategy and a minor in Finance. I have also had some experience from politics. The key takeaway for me was to more carefully consider the needs of different parties and come up with a workable solution that leaves stakeholders satisfied. Potential conflicts of interest I am a holder of MKR and currently it is about half my crypto portfolio. The maker portion is about two years salary. The other half is in ETH. I hold a diversified portfolio of stocks and funds. My primary income is not from Maker, nor do I receive any form of compensation outside of MakerDAO for my participation within. Waiver of liability I have read and pledge to follow the Recognized Delegate Code of Conduct. As such I will to the best of my ability act in good faith to the best interests of the Maker Protocol. I will maintain communication regarding my stance on the various issues that is voted on. By delegating to me you acknowledge and agree that JustinCase will not be held liable for any damages caused by my participation in the Maker Protocol or because of any votes cast while acting as a delegate.
content.GPT-summary: The post is an explanation of JustinCase's delegate platform for MakerDAO. The author explains their core values and what they will work towards if elected as a delegate. They also address potential conflicts of interest and pledge to follow the Recognized Delegate Code of Conduct. A third party could give constructive criticism or ask questions about the proposal, and the author is open to collaboration.

content.content: Polls ending November 15. 2021 Local Liquidation Limit Adjustments for ETH-A, ETH-B, ETH-C, WBTC-A and WSTETH-A - November 15, 2021 Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal will in my opinion improve our ability to maintain our obligations through lowering the risk of failing to liquidate assets when needed. Rates Proposal - November 15, 2021 Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal is in essence a question of balancing risk with growth. The carrot is that reducing risk comes with some extra revenue. Offboard the AAVE-A Vault Type - November 15, 2021 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Conflicted between profitability and maintaining obligations I landed on the side of profitability. Due to the lack of an entity to communicate with one must assume that stakeholders in this case are “communicating with their assets” and the lack of profitable interest is an indication this collateral type is not needed right now. Offboard the BAL-A Vault Type - November 15, 2021 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Conflicted between profitability and maintaining obligations I landed on the side of profitability. Due to the lack of an entity to communicate with one must assume that stakeholders in this case are “communicating with their assets” and the lack of profitable interest is an indication this collateral type is not needed right now. Offboard the COMP-A Vault Type - November 15, 2021 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Conflicted between profitability and maintaining obligations I landed on the side of profitability. Due to the lack of an entity to communicate with one must assume that stakeholders in this case are “communicating with their assets” and the lack of profitable interest is an indication this collateral type is not needed right now. Change of Covenants for P1-DROP (Peoples Company Series 1) - November 15, 2021 Voted: Yes Reasoning: I can see the concerns regarding the legal structures and the murkiness regarding the risk. However in this case it is not enough for me to overcome my default stance of maintaining obligations. If we want to unwind from the current structure I think we should start a process on that and signal our intentions well in advance. Preferably we should work out a new structure that doesn’t leave our counterparts hanging.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Template - [Executive Proposal] Onboarding WBTC-B, Increasing WBTC-A Stability Fee, Change of Covenants for P1-DROP, Offboarding Collaterals - November 19, 2021. Voted: Yes Reasoning: The poll that ended November 15. covers almost all of this executive and I voted yes in the relevant polls. The piece included is adding the WBTC-B vault type. This is a riskier type of vault but has a higher stability fee. It mirrors the existing ETH-B vaults. The likely results of introducing this vault is that some portion of WBTC will flow to this new type of vault. Overall it might increase risk somewhat but it is bundled with a change that will reduce risk in the same vault type. I approve of this change.

Polls ending November 22, 2021 Ratification Poll for Adding the Deco Fixed Rate Core Unit (DECO-001) Voted: Abstain Reasoning: This is a very interesting proposal introducing a possibility for getting fixed interests in vaults. With this proposal I see some of my principles being in opposition. On the pro side we’re looking at a growth opportunity in capturing value from actors that require fixed rates, we’re getting more predictable income which can serve as insurance for when markets turn, and we open up the potential to other applications being built onto this. On the con side I see this adding more complexity, both on the technical side and for users to relate to. There has also been raised some concerns on the legal side which hasn’t been fully answered. Overall I’m torn enough that I vote abstain. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, RWF-001 (MIP40c3-SP39) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I believe Makers greatest growth potential lies within Real World Finance. The team so far has done great work and I have full confidence they will put the funds to good use. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP40) Voted: Yes Resoning: Hardly controversial this makes some minor changes to the budget, but most importantly extends until then end of the second quarter of 2022. Ratification Poll for the Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Voted: Yes Reasoning: If we are to maintain our obligations we need to ensure the security and integrity of the protocol. Leaving that to chance seems ill advised. Ratification Poll for Adding Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit, SAS-001 Voted: Yes Reasoning: One of our key obligation is making sure the protocol stays collateralized. In order to do so we need to make sure the liquidation auctions are working as intended. This seems to me to be a step in the right direction to make sure we live up to our obligations. Ratification Poll for Real-World Finance Core Unit MKR Compensation, RWF-001 Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal establishes MKR compensation for the Real World Asset core unit. Having compensation in MKR increases the teams alignment with that of other MKR holders. I believe this is a prudent step and in line with what is done in other core units. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, MKT-001 (MIP40c3-SP33) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal extends the budget of Content Production until the end of the first half of 2022. Having core units comes with the obligation to fund them so this is an easy yes. Ratification Poll for Supplement to Collateral Onboarding Application (MIP6c3-SP1) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal adds a list of further requirements to any onboarding applications for real world assets. As we cross the boundaries from the virtual to the physical there are information needs that needs to be filled. This proposal helps fill that need for information, and is something we should expect anyone wishing to onboard real world collateral to answer.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Polls ending November 25. 2021 Add WBTC-C as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is the complementary vault type to WBTC-B that I discussed in relation to the executive of November 19. WBTC is a less risky vault than WBTC-A and given the volume in those vaults I think it is worth it to provide a less risky alternative. This also helps balance out the increased risks that comes from the WBTC-B vaults. The downside is less revenue generated. Increase the System Surplus Buffer Voted: 1. No increase 2. Increse Stability buffer to 90M and the limit by 0.67M/week 3. Increase Stability buffer to 90M and the limit by 1M/Week Reasoning: This is an issue I feel strongly about and one that is at the center of my delegate platform. I believe that we should strive to maintain some level at burn as long as we run a profit. Ideally we would do this with a set fraction and set fractions going to other purposes. Due to technical limitations we’re right now constrained to burning everything as long as the surplus buffer is full and nothing when it is not. In order to fully evaluate this change it isn’t enough to look at the surplus buffer limit but also other events that contribute to either filling or emptying the surplus buffer. Oracles Core Unit has put in a request to pull 8.7M in expenses. At the current profit levels that would take around a month to build back. Granted there might be mitigating steps taken but that is going to shave off a week or so of this time.If we start increasing the surplus buffer at the same time it’s going to delay the start of the burn by around two more weeks at 1M a week increase. My preference at this time would therefore be no increase until we are back on 60M and then a gradual increase to 90M. Add a GUSD Peg Stability Module Voted: Yes Reasoning: The most important obligation of the protocol is to keep the peg. This gives us another asset that will help maintain it and it diversifies us from other assets all in all a big plus in my book. Increase the Aave D3M Maximum Debt Ceiling Voted: Yes Reasoning: The D3M is a way for us to stabilize the interest of DAI and to capture some of the value from its use outside of MakerDAO. I appreciate the gradual phasing in of this and given that risk as deemed it safe to do so support increasing the debt ceiling. This will also help grow our profitability.

Onboarding New Vault Types, Parameter Changes, and Core Unit Budget Distributions Voted: Yes Reasoning: The only proposal in this executive I did not vote “Yes” to was to add the Deco fixed rate core unit. As for the changes to parameters I gave an account of my position in the previous post. All in all I see no reason to not support this executive even though I might have wished it to be slightly different.

content.content: Polls ending November 29. 2021 Community Greenlight Poll - MONETALIS (Monetalis Wholesale SME Green Growth Lending) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is a real world asset project that seeks to utilize capital from the protocol to fund loans to small and medium enterprises in the UK to drive green change. This is very much in the direction laid out in the case for green money. It is also a fairly substantial sum that is question. It seems to me this project also carries a potential to scale further. Overall I think this is a compelling case for both growing the profits of the protocol and getting more DAI into circulation. Community Greenlight Poll - SB-frOGI (SolidBlock Red Frog Digital Coin) Voted: No Reasoning: This one took a lot of thinking, but in the end I landed on that I believe it is best for Maker DAO to focus their limited capacity elsewhere at this time. This project is also a real world project asking for funding to real estate projects. In this project there is the added complexity of having another tokenization model to deal with. I don’t see any immediate scaling with this project either. That being said we might find room for this or something similar further down the line.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving feedback on proposal

content.content: Polls ending 02. December 2021 Increase the Dust Parameter for Most Vault Types Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is an unfortunate step because it increases the bar to get access to the majority of our vaults. I fear higher dust limits will limit our growth. We have no control over the prices of gas however and have to take steps to protect the protocol from losses in the event of liquidations. Hopefully we can find solutions that makes these vaults more accessible again in the near future. Increase the Dust Parameter for ETH-B Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is also a case of protecting vaults in the event of liquidations due to high gas prices. In this particular case I’m less concerned than with the other vaults as ETH-B represents a more risky vault and I think we should be able to expect more from users of such vaults. Of course ideally we want to find solutions that we don’t have to for these kinds of vaults too. Use the MakerDAO Treasury to Fund MKR Expenses Voted: Yes Reasoning: Part of the draw of the MKR token is the narrative that there is 1.000.000 tokens or less in existence. As long as we have a treasury of them I vastly prefer to draw from this over issuing new ones. Primarily I would not support issuing new MKR at all, but if we are to do it we need to have a long and good discussion about how we are going to go about it. Issuing MKR is burning in reverse and we’ve seen the effects of postponing the burn. Add GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: It’s always nice to be able to support onboarding of a new vault and watch Maker grow. This goes straight to my principle of wanting to grow profitability. I want to add that in the light of the recent discussions surrounding offboarding of other vaults that by taking this stance we should also be willing to let this vault run for a while to give it a chance to show it’s worth. One Time Payment to the GovComms CU to Deal with Budget Issues Voted: Yes Reasoning: In the field of human endeavours mistakes are going to be made. I believe in correcting honest mistakes with a minimum amount of friction. Hopefully we can learn something from this and avoid similar mistakes in the future. Perhaps this can also help build a case for making a separate accounting CU. Parameter Changes Proposal - MakerDAO Open Market Committee Voted: Yes Reasoning: In my view these changes to parameters are largely based on changing market conditions. Most, if all of them, are tweaks so there shouldn’t be any dramatic effects. I’m happy to see that this will add more revenue and thus profitability to the protocol. Add CurveLP-stETH-ETH as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another ETH vault. I predict that staked Ethereum is just going to grow in popularity as we go forward. Making a vault for this asset is prudent and in line with growing the profitability of the protocol. I am a little concerned that we are setting the dust limit too low in light of the proposal of increasing it from 10k to 15k for all similar vault types.

Parameter Changes, Delegate Compensation, Vault Onboarding Voted: Yes Reasoning: The parameter changes in this executive is mostly minor rate increases and most likely will help increase the profits of the protocol. We have the unfortunately necessary changes to dust limits. It also contains onboarding of GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A vault type as well as corrections to the Governance Communication Core Unit and the payout of the delegate compensation. All in all there are some nice changes here.

content.content: Polls ending 09. December 2021 Adjust wstETH-A System Parameters Voted: Yes Reasoning: The main purpose of this proposal is to increase the debt ceiling of the wstETH-A vault (Staked ETH). Along with this there are some other parameter changes that will allow for faster debt growth and quicker liquidations. It is always nice to see a new vault type gain popularity and given that we do not incur undue risk I happily support these changes. Growth in our vaults leads to growth in our profit. Adjust MATIC-A System Parameters Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal is to increase the debt ceiling of the MATIC-A vault. This vault type has survived two recent attempts to offboard it so it is really good to see it gain some traction. I think it also serves as a reminder that we need to have some patience with different vault types as they may not start out profitable. Now that the momentum is positive I think it’s urgent that we allow it to fulfill its potential. We may have gotten off on the wrong foot but right now it seems that we’re heading for a bright future.

content.content: Executive December 10. 2021. Parameter Changes, Switching MKR Vesting Source Voted: Yes Reasoning: A fairly small executive this time. I voted yes in all the polls going into this executive so voting yes for the executive is straight forward. The three proposals were:  Adjusting wstETH-A System Parameters Adjust MATIC-A System Parameters Use MakerDAO Treasury to Fund MKR Expenses  These can be found on the polls ending on the 02. and 09. of December. I’m particularly happy about the changes to MATIC-A parameters as I see that as a positive change borne from community interaction and turning something of a losing situation into a potential very fruitful cooperation.

content.content: Polls ending December 16. 2021 DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) Debt Ceiling Targeting Voted: 1. Neither Indicated Percentage of Real AAVEv2 DAI Supply 2. 25% of Real AAVEv2 DAI Supply 3. 30% of Real AAVEv2 DAI Supply Reasoning: I believe the D3M modules represents a useful way to provide DAI through third parties, and especially for users who are locked out of participating in Maker Vaults due to dust limits. As such I’m happy to support proposals that increase the amounts we can provide. Unfortunately in this particular case risk recommended keeping the supply to 15-20%. I highly value the expert opinion of risk and would therefore primarily prefer to keep the supply at those levels. That being said, we are in an expansion phase and as such we might have to condone a little elevated risk for some time so I’ll support further increase although at a lower priority. DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) Net Rates Spread Voted: Yes Reasoning: This poll is tied to the previous one. The target rate of the D3M module is going to have a direct effect on how much of the debt ceiling we can utilize. The lower the rates the higher the utility. On the flip side, lower rates on the D3M makes it more attractive to borrow through Aave rather directly from Maker Vaults. This reduction in target rate makes it a little more attractive to borrow through Aave but still for the majority of use cases it’s cheaper to use Maker vaults directly. I’m not overly concerned how we put the DAI into circulation because at the end of the day, Maker DAO ends up with the interest from the issue either directly or through the D3M. Overall I expect this to increase DAI supply from current levels. Recognised Delegate Compensation Trial Performance Modifier Voted: Abstain Reasoning: I was asked about delegate compensation in my introduction video and I will restate some of what I said there. In matters of delegate compensation I will as a main rule always abstain. That is because I see it as impossible to hold an unbiased view on the matter as long as I am an acting delegate. My preferred solution to questions of this type to be solved without any involvement of delegates at all.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Polls ending December 20. 2021 Community Greenlight Poll - aUST (Anchor TerraUSD) Voted: No Reasoning: This is a onboarding request for a new type of collateral. It’s always hard to turn down new potential members of the Maker family but in this case the risk seems too high to warrant an inclusion at this time. Monet-supply made a compelling risk arguement here. Hopefully the issues can be adressed and we can have a future fruitful collaberation. Community Greenlight Poll - G-UNIv3-DAIUSDP (Gelato UniswapV3 DAI-USDP LP Token) Voted: Abstain Reasoning: This is another onboarding application for a collateral type. For this collateral I fear we might be too late to the party and even so I have doubts this will prove profitable. I don’t think it will pose a direct risk to the protocol however so we might try it out but I think our resources are better employed elsewhere. All in all I am therefore abstaining from voting on this particular collateral type. It will be interesting to hear further evaluation from our Core Units on this.

content.content: Polls ending January 13. 2022 Prioritize Onboarding a Compound DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Compound is another big player in DeFi space. Establishing a D3M with them allows us to capture some revenue from people unwilling or unable to interact with Maker directly. As we continue to add D3Ms we need to be mindful not only of the individual risks posed by each one but the systemic and cumulative risks that goes into the combination of them. On a more positive note I’m excited to see us grow and find new ways to generate revenue. Raise the Emergency Shutdown Module (ESM) Threshold Voted: Yes Reasoning: It is important to maintain an emergency option, but lately we have seen a few actors getting close to being able to trigger this shutdown on their own. It is also a potential malicious attack vector for someone looking to get rid of a bothersome competitor at 7,5% of the value of the protocol. This move increases the threshold to just over 10%. A step in a safer direction without making it impossible to use. Prioritize DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) for Maple Finance Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another Direct Deposit Module, this one still differs that it’s not connected to a big established actor in DeFi. The proposal is interesting and even though there are parameters that needs defining I think it’s interesting enough that it warrants looking further into. Increase the Dust Parameter for Select LP Token Vaults Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is more or less housecleaning from the last round of increasing dust limits. While I regret the necessity of doing so it must be done to maintain risk at an acceptable level. Hopefully we will see gas prices come down or our own L2 solutions come online so we can become more accessable. Proposal - Recover DAI Locked in Optimism Escrow Voted: No Reasoning: This is a very reasonable request. In general I think we should make an effort to recover these funds, but I also recognize there are a lot of others who have also lost funds in similar circumstances. Before we do these kinds of recoveries I believe we ought to have a policy in place that describes how we handle these kinds of situations. Such a policy is even being worked on as we speak. While I recognize the terrible situation the entity that lost those funds to be in, I want to reassure that we are talking about a delay until we can treat everyone fairly. I would also like to underline that a delay is vastly preferable to funds being lost permanently which is a very real possibility in other parts of crypto. The proposal as written is a one-off solution for a single actor. It will leave us open to accusations that we are catering to a select group, further alienating smaller actors.

This one contains the recovery of DAI that I voted “no” to in the polls. As such I believe in supporting the community’s chosen course of action and putting it into effect.

content.content: Polls ending January 20. 2022 PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: I believe in delegation in order to not get lost in the weeds of deciding every detail on the DAO level. Trying to sustain such a detailed focus is going to lead to governance overload and result in worse outcomes rather than good ones. As a result I’m happy we’ve established the Open Market Committee to suggest changes in parameters to various vaults. My first assumption will be that they’ve done a good job and then review it. Having done so I find no reason not to support the proposed changes. Decrease the GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A Liquidation Ratio Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal is not covered by the mandate of the Open Market Committee. It follows in the same vein as the previous proposal and my reasoning remains much the same. I can’t see this proposal be to the detriment of our users nor to increase our risk unacceptably. So all in all I support it.

Polls ending January 24. 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - OGN (Origin Protocol) Voted: Yes Reasoning: After a helpful reminder from Long For Wisdom here, and getting assurances that action is being taken to reduce our backlog of earlier greenlit collateral onboarding applications my assesment is that the application is strong enough for CUs to start doing a real assessment on the validity. One aspect I’m going to particular look for in the next round of assessment is going to be profitability. I want to avoid onboarding a collateral that takes too long to turn profitable and having to go through a process of offboarding shortly after. Community Greenlight Poll - OUSD (Origin Dollar) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Much the same reasoning as the previous collateral (in fact they are part of the same application). Hopefully this can turn fruitful, but will have to be examined closer. Community Greenlight Poll - RBLD (Robinland Holdings) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another greenlight poll. I’m really happy we are getting traction on our backlog which was my main concern regarding this application. The way @Scarlet_Chen har interacted with the community does her and her project credit and should be looked to for inspiration for other applicants. Concerns have been raised and answered. It seems to me there is a lot of alignment between Robinland and Maker. Further work by the CUs will determine just how compatible we are but given the level of communication so far I’m more than hopeful an agreement can be reached. Community Greenlight Poll - TUSD-PSM (TrueUSD) Voted: No Reasoning: It’s always a sad day when I need to turn down an application because I know the amount of work involved. However I still think it’s better to give an up front answer when I don’t think this proposal will make it through the process. This is not the first time TUSD have applied to Maker. Unfortunately I don’t see any of the concerns that were raised in the previous application have been addressed and thus I don’t see any reason this one will get another outcome. Transparency is a very important quality and one fundamental to proper assessment of risk. When that is lacking there is little hope moving forward. Community Greenlight Poll - USDap (BondAppetit) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another greenlight poll. This one holds promise as well. It will naturally add to the workload of the CUs but again I think a closer assessment is worth the effort involved. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, ORA-001 (Oracle Gas Costs) (MIP40c3-SP45) Voted: Yes Reasoning: An increase in the budget for Oracles mainly to account for expected increases in gas costs and to repay the foundation for fronting gas costs for us for the end of 2021. One of my core values is maintaining obligations and repaying debt is a very serious obligation. I’m happy to see this settled but I do wish when we interact with another entity that the documentation would be clearer. I expect other partners will expect the same from us as we go forward. Ratification Poll for Onboarding Tech-Ops Core Unit (TECH-001) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This core unit is meant to maintain the infrastructure of the protocol. A vital function and I’m  happy they get established. This is an easy proposal to support. As a support function it’s somewhat harder to define clear goals for it, but what we have so far will have to serve. Ratification Poll for the Strategic Finance Core Unit (SF-001) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is a core unit I have high hopes for. Bringing two highly talented individuals together in order to get a closer look at the overall financial health of the protocol and to assist in strategic decision making when it comes to the allocation of capital. I suspect there is room for improvement in this area and I believe this core unit is capable of finding it. Ratification Poll for Collateral Offboarding Process (MIP62) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Maintaining obligations is one of my core values and one of the keys to that is to manage expectations. Well thought out and founded processes is one tool to manage expectations. Our experience with previous collateral offboarding has revealed the need for a better process and now one has been approved. I’m really happy this is coming. Ratification Poll for Core Unit Budget, SNE-001 (MIP40c3-SP47) Voted: Yes Reasoning: If we want to remain relevant in the cryptoshere we need to develop for the sidechains. Granting this budget allows work to continue to adopt Maker to L2 and has my full support. Ratification Poll for Bug Bounty Program for MakerDAO Critical Infrastructure (MIP64) Voted: Yes Reasoning: If we want to maintain our obligations then we need to make sure our protocol remains safe. This program is designed to help us uncover weaknesses before they become serious issues. As is the case with all security measures I really hope it’s unnecessary, but in a complex world this is rarely the case. Security can be an underappreciated field but this proposal will help secure Maker’s value. Ratification Poll for Maker Keeper Network (MIP63) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Keepers are another essential part of the Maker ecosystem. They are responsible for many things but perhaps the most prominent is being the counterpart in liquidation auctions. Needless to say should those auctions fail, our whole protocol fails. This proposal makes it easier for third party keepers to interface with Maker. This should make their jobs easier and might attract more keepers over time. Ratification Poll for Offboarding Content Production Core Unit (MKT-001) Voted: No Reasoning: This is another proposal that goes straight to my value of maintaining obligations. In my view once we bring on a core unit we have certain responsibilities towards said unit. One of those to me is to act in a predictable manner. In this particular case I am of the opinion that Content Production has not received enough time to prove their value. I also think there has been a clash of expectations in what this core unit is supposed to deliver. First and foremost I think there should be a clearer process for how we offboard both core units and facilitators. Given that we are in a situation without those I will need a clearer statement of exact statements of what the core unit were supposed to deliver and what they haven’t delivered. Even showing that I think it’s reasonable to give the core unit a chance to correct for a failure to deliver before we offboard. Offboarding carries several costs. It has the opportunity cost of all the things that is not done before we optionally onboard a new core unit, and it has the reputation cost of others seeing how we conduct our offboardings. It may also cause members of other core units to reconsider their commitment to Maker given that it has been shown that is a more unstable place of employment than earlier thought. In light of things that have come up during this discussion I do think Content Production do have some earlier promises they need to deliver on, but they deserve a chance to do so. Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding for RWF-001 (MIP41c4-SP27) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I believe that Real World Finance holds a lot of promise when it comes to growing Maker. As such I’m paying extra close attention to what happens in this core unit. I’m happy the process of changing facilitator is about to come to an end. Both the person stepping down and the person stepping up as facilitator have impressed me with their insights on the forum and I’m confident Real World Finance is going to do great things for Maker the coming years. Ratification Poll for Development & UX Core Unit Budget - DUX-001 (MIP40c3-SP52) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is minor adjustments to the budget of Development & UX. I don’t see anything unreasonable in this. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget - Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling (SES-001) (MIP40c3-SP55) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another mostly technical adjustment of the budget. It also extends it but I don’t see anything controversial so I will support it.

Executive January 21. 2022 MOMC Parameter Changes, Decrease the GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A Liquidation Ratio Voted: Yes Reasoning: With the recent downturn in the markets the adjustments to fees just became even more relevant. We can already see a fairly substantial reduction in our vaults. Given the prevailing market sentiment we are likely to see even more reductions but this may help lessen the reductions.

Urgent Executive January 24. 2022 Temporarily Prevent Surplus (flap) Auctions and MKR Burn Voted: Yes Reasoning: With the recent sharp downturn in the markets and the demonstration that the current surplus auctions handles large amounts of burn poorly it seems more than prudent to temporarily halt burning by artificially raising the surplus buffer. This was done as an emergency meassure until a better solution can be placed into effect. I urged the community to make that a priority here. From what I’ve gathered the most immediate fix is to put in a throttle on the rate of the surplus auctions. The more long term solutions will be to implement liquidity 2.0 (reverse dutch auctions) auctions. This is the type of auctions we use for our liquidation auctions. Hopefully the market turbulence will settle soon and a workable solution will be in place. As much as I support keeping the burn going, the primary concern must be for the immediate health and safety of the protocol. I will work to restore the burn as soon as it is safe to do so.

Executive January 28. 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: The main effect of this executive is the distribution of funds to various core units to maintain their operations. Of not is the start of the new strategic finance core unit and the substantial sum that goes to the oracles core unit. Included in the funds for oracles is the establishment of an emergency fund to ensure that there will be sufficient ETH available even in the event of a massive spike in gas costs. I have voted in favor of all the budget proposals earlier so it’s an easy support. The one immediate downside I see is that this will lower our surplus buffer by ~15%, which is a little bit unnerving given that we this same week suspended the burn due to concerns of inefficiencies in burning as well as the worry of a cascading market downturn resulting in bad debt for the protocol. In the absence of liquidation penalties it is going to take us around a month to build back that same buffer.

Polls ending February 07. 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - STABLE-NOTE (2 to 10 Year Duration US Treasury Securities) Voted: Yes Reasoning: The essence of this proposal is to divert some of the USDC that we currently hold into US Treasury securities. The advantage of doing so is to move counterparty risk from USDC over to Stable+. A version of putting our eggs in more baskets. As an added incentive there is the possibility of a low yield over no yield. The proposed structure leaves some questions regarding the experience of Stable+ to handle such transactions, it also leaves some questions on debt portfolio management and a clear picture of the total risk incurred to Maker. However, this is a greenlight poll. GFX Labs and Paperimperium have so far shown an excellent willingness to engage with the community in addressing concerns and at this stage I have no reason to doubt they will continue to do so. I am not certain this proposal will pass scrutiny once more details are put under the microscope, but on the other hand I’m not convince it will be rejected either. Our growing holdings of USDC should be resolved in some way and this proposal has at least someone working on it. Community Greenlight Poll - STABLE-TBILL (US Treasury Securities Up To 12 Months Duration) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal is the same as the above but with different maturity times for the securities. As such the reasoning laid out above also applies here. From my point of view, a shorter duration of the securities gives up less of the liquidity that is a major reason of having the PSM and thus probably is the one with the most promise.

Poll ending February 3. 2022 PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: I commented on the discussion. My default stance is to support the Open Market Committee in their work. Watching rates, and thus our revenues, fall is not pleasant but for now necessary. If we continue in this direction however I’m concerned for our profit margins, and that we risk getting into the same position we were in the summer of '21 where revenue barely keeps up with our expenses. Especially concerning is the added effect the introduction of the Nexo vault will have on our overall revenue. I think we need to take the time and effort to do a closer study on the relationship between changing rates and debt retention so we don’t end up lowering our rates too much for too little gain.

Executive February 5. 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: The executive is the formal approval of previous polls and as such not a place to make a stand unless there is an imminent threat to the protocol in anything suggested. As such the default action is to vote “yes” to maintain the obligations to ensure proper governance. This executive contains issues such as raising the emergency shutdown threshold, approving rate changes proposed by the Open Market Committee, various budget changes in the core units and delegate compensation for January. I have laid out more detailed reasoning on the various polls listed above. I did not vote in opposition to any of the issues.

Polls ending February 10. 2022 Extend the Delegate Compensation Trial Voted: Abstain Reasoning: In matters concerning delegate compensation I will in most cases abstain. This is due to the inherent conflict of interest that is present in this issue. Offloading TUSD-A Voted: 1. Activate liquidations 2. Offload to a new TUSD-PSM with 0 Debt Ceiling Reasoning: The majority of TUSD vaults are undercollateralized at this point. As such it is time to correct our balance sheet. Given that the recent proposal to enact a TUSD PSM got overwhelming negative response it seems prudent to attempt another route if possible. Activating liquidations involves less engineering effort and thus lower opportunity cost. Either option is likely to result in losses to the protocol, but with liquidations it’s quick and relatively painless. Going by my principle on selecting the less complex solution I will favor liquidations first. Introduce Rate Limiting into the Flapper Voted: Yes Reasoning: The most important reason for voting “yes” on this issue is because it is the quickest way to return to a normalized state following an urgent executive. After the massive wave of liquidations January 21. we passed an urgent executive the following week raising the surplus buffer to 250M. This was primarily done to protect the protocol from inefficient surplus auctions but also over worries that in a cascading liquidation scenario we might incur larger losses than our current surplus buffer can handle. In order to achieve these changes quickly an urgent executive was proposed and passed. When we deviate from standard governance process due to specific events or unforseen circumstances we need to return to a state of standard governance process. That means that any change has to be temporary in nature. If we do not change back then every urgent or emergency measure needs to be evaluated not only on the merits of the immediate situation, but also on the long term consequences. If we need to carefully weigh the long term consequences we should use the normal governance process to make sure we’ve carefully considered all relevant facts, and their probable consequences. Failing to revert to normality will put a question on every future use of urgent or emergency executives. At best they will be slowed down, and at worst they will be denied because the long term consequences are unacceptable. In my opinion a rate limiter solves the immediate issues and thus allows us to return to a normal state of operation. A rate limiter will remove the worst inefficiencies of surplus auctions (making it almost impossible to get away with extremely low bids). It is also going to give us an immediate injection to the surplus buffer in the event of mass liquidations. This temporary shield will help us avoid us if the market trend continues downwards and a further wave of liquidations hit. Would I like to see a more efficient way to burn our surplus DAI? Absolutely, but the place to discuss that is from a position of normal governance.

Poll ending February 17. 2022 Increase the PSM-GUSD Debt Ceiling Voted: Yes Reasoning: The Price Stability Modules (PSM) are designed to assist in keeping the peg of DAI to as close as 1$ as possible. Keeping the peg is the most fundamental obligation the protocol has to deliver on. Having a variety of PSMs reduces the individual counterparty risk, making us more robust in the face of potential troubles with either one of them. The GUSD PSM has shown a potential to reach its current debt ceiling. Increasing this keeps us within acceptable risk levels. As such I support raising the debt ceiling with 10M.

Poll ending February 24. 2022 MakerMan Retroactive Delegate Compensation Voted: Yes Reasoning: This poll is about whether or not to retroactively grant the delegate MakerMan compensation for November. The reason it is brought up is because he missed the performance requirements by less than a % point. It is also worth noting that the requirements were at the time just introduced so a single missed vote would have big consequences for the performance. Given the rather large difference in payment that 1% constitutes my opinion is that MakerMan should get compensation for the month in question. This compensation is also not a full compensation but rather the reduced compensation that was introduced in the following month. All things considered this seems like a reasonable course of action to me and thus I support this poll.

Executive February 25. 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: A small executive containing retroactive compensation to Makerman and raising the debt ceiling of PSM-GUSD. In the polls I voted in favor of both of these. Even if I didn’t support both of the above issues I would still support the executive as a whole. To me it is important that governance does not become blocked and a delegate should recognize when their view is not the majority view. Abstaining or refusing to support an executive should in my opinion only be considered if there is a reasonable expectation that the executive will be actively harmful to the protocol.

Polls ending on February 28. 2022 Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding to DUX-001 Voted: Yes Reasoning: The voluntary change of facilitator in the DUX core unit should serve as an example for others. Recognizing when to change roles is a major strength in any organization. I’m very happy to welcome @0xdeniz as the new facilitator and expect he’ll do great work in bringing the core unit forward. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, RISK-001 Voted: Yes Reasoning: While the increase in the proposed budget might seem excessive at first glance we’re talking about a substantial increase in contributors. In my opinion RISK have been delivering value and I expect they will be able to add even more with an expanded team. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget - Collateral Engineering Services, CES-001 (MIP40c3-SP57) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is to continue funding Collateral Engineering Services (CES). CES is an important piece in the growth and maintainance of Maker. It is also involved in further developing real world assets. After reviewing the budget proposal I find it reasonable and thus support it. Ratification Poll for MIP55 Amendments (MIP4c2-SP16) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal is an ammendment to MIP-55. The main purpose of the ammendment was to clarify the DAI limits on which kind of proposals go to the weekly and which proposals goes into the monthly governance cycle. More clarity means less complexity and less room for error, as such I support the proposal. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, Immunefi Security (IS-001) (MIP40c3-SP58) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is a 12 month funding for the Immunefi Security core unit. Maintaining the security of the protocol is almost as important as maintaining the peg. If we fail on either the protocol is dead. As such I support this proposal that helps us achieve the needed security. As a side note, I wish all the core units operated with the same time frame. I suspect a 12 month timeframe makes the most sense as a balance between potential losses and governance overhead. Ratification Poll for Onboard/Amend Keeper Network - Tech-Ops (MIP63c4-SP1) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Every organization needs someone to be able to grease the wheels to keep operations running. This is the role of the Tech-Ops core unit and I’m happy to have them join the family. Ratification Poll for Onboarding the Maker Talent Core Unit (MT-001) Voted: No Reasoning: I want to start this by saying I believe in @manomad and the team he has assembled. In my view, the protocol is now grown to the size of an organization that is going to need a more diverse set of skills from its contributors. As such I welcome the creation of this core unit. However, this core units primary audience and customer base are the other core units. As the core units are autonomous and free to choose whether they want to employ the expertise Maker Talent brings to the table I believe it is critical for the success of this core unit that there is sufficient will among the other core units to actually use them. I want to set up core units for success and not for failing and necessitating an off-boarding process 6 months down the line. After reviewing feedback from other parts of the community I am of the opinion that the support at this time is insufficient. That being said I think that is possible to remedy, but this proposal should brought up again in the next governance cycle. It is never pleasant to have to take a negative stance but I really want Maker Talent to fly and serve as an inspiration and a guiding beacon for bringing new areas of expertise into the Maker community. To achieve this they deserve the very best starting position. Ratification Poll for Intangible Asset Assignment (MIP60) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal brings more clarity on which actors manage which intangible assets. Coordination of this kind is to be expected as the protocol grows and is important to get in place before it turns into a point of dispute. I support this effort to bring more clarity to this field and the processes it outlines. A personal note The events of this past week has been dramatic and I have been personally affected given that my in-laws reside in Ukraine. I hope everyone takes a moment to reflect on the blessing it is to live in safety. Having to help my extended family survive and get to safety while having to decide on what to leave behind has been heartbreaking. I fear this situation may interfere somewhat with my work, but I hope the situation will be resolved peacefully soon.
Justin, praying for your in-laws and their safety.  The Ukrainians are re-writing the definition of heroism.  Slava Ukraini!

Polls ending 03. March 2022 PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: Yet another proposal from the Open Market Committee to lower stability fees. Fortunately it’s only marginally and with a corresponding increase in the Aave D3M we might be able to recoup some revenue as well. I’m looking forward to the time when we once again can increase stability fees. Even so I think its important that we react to changing market conditions and maintain Makers reputation as a fair actor, so I support this proposal. Adding Rate Limiter to Flap Auctions Voted: Yes Reasoning: I’m excited to see the Rate Limiter get ready to get implemented. This have been in the works since flappy Friday and will both help secure the protocol in the event of mass liquidations and help avoid inefficient surplus auctions by limiting the maximum number of parallel ones. It’s sad that this change goes into effect without restoring the surplus buffer as it is functionally useless until we do, but such is life.

Executive March 04. 2022 Core Unit Budget Distributions, Recognized Delegate Compensation, MOMC Parameter Changes Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another week another executive. Once again a fairly small executive. Supporting the governance process. This one contains core unit budget distributions, recognized delegate compensations and parameter changes proposed by MOMC.

Poll ending 07. March 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - PUNK (NTFX CryptoPunk) Voted: No Reasoning: Greenlight polls are supposed to be fairly low bar. Even so we’re still having some backlog issues. Further on, we’re seeing a downward trend in market sentiment and crypto asset valuations. We are also seeing our profit margins shrink. As such and given the volatile and fairly small market cap of the proposed collateral I am certain that Maker is better served focusing its efforts elsewhere.

Out of Schedule Executive proposal 09. March 2022 Mitigate Post-Shutdown Flash Loan Vulnerability Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is an out of schedule executive to address a security flaw that can be exploited in the event of a triggering of the emergency shutdown module. It doesn’t provide an immediate danger to the protocol, but any security risk should be taken care of as soon as possible. Keeping the protocol secure is of utmost importance if the protocol expect to retain faith among users and stakeholders. As such I support this executive.

Polls ending 10. March 2022 Offboarding Parameters for TUSD-A Voted: Yes Reasoning: Earlier it was decided that we should offboard TUSD due to a variety of factors. This proposal sets the parameters to ensure that happens. While this is going to result in some losses to the protocol, those losses are already here, this is merely acknowledging them. It also cleans up our books by no longer appearing to generate revenue from these vaults which we know we will never receive. Reinstate Surplus Buffer Lerp Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is an issue that is very important to me and frankly one of the reasons I even got started as a delegate. The way its been handled by the protocol has shaken my faith in the project. What was supposed to be a immediate response to a threatening situation has in bad faith been turned into a question on whether or not we should have burn at all. Turning off the burn took one vote totally bypassing the whole of the ordinary governance process, but trying to get it restored has so far taken 2 different signal requests, 1 executive and now we’re on the third signal request to try to make it happen. It is increasingly clear to me that actors within the Maker community, especially those working directly with core units are openly opposed to burning MKR. That is understandable, after all their pay comes directly from the surplus buffer, they have a direct economic incentive to make sure it is perpetually filled up. However, where does that leave MKR holders? If this proposal doesn’t pass there is no economic incentive to hold MKR tokens. With current levels of profitability (which have been falling dramatically for the past months) burning may resume in 2026(!). I have seen fantasies of having a surplus buffer of one billion or more, but nothing in our pipeline is showing any promise of even filling the 250M that its currently set for. Even the argument that the surplus buffer has anything to do with risk to the protocol is rapidly losing relevance as we are already between the 2-3% of surplus to non-stablecoin ratio. In addition we have now implemented a rate limiter to further protect the protocol in a cascading downwards scenario. Should this proposal fail I’m certain that we will see MKR tokens continue to decline in value relative to ETH as only the larger holders of MKR will maintain their positions and then only because the limited liquidity makes an exit impossible.

JustinCase:  Should this proposal fail I’m certain that we will see MKR tokens continue to decline in value relative to ETH as only the larger holders of MKR will maintain their positions and then only because the limited liquidity makes an exit impossible.   Realize that there is zero correlation to MKR price to burn. I appreciate you taking the burn side here JustinCase and keep plugging away.    If taking what resources we have now and putting them to work to grow DAI, and hence revenues, is less important compared to throwing DAI capital assets away to remove MKR assets off the book at high prices while thinking, somehow magically, Maker will be able to sell MKR to raise cash (flop) when Maker has a surplus hole is the best use of assets at this time. Evidence from Black Thursday stands in stark contrast to the whitepaper assertion and promise and as the best evidence that the above is NOT the best approach to build value for MKR holders. If I am a DAI holder (and I am BTW, but really I am a net DAI borrower) that got left with a 6% hole in my collateral backing for an entire week during Black Thursday I have to wonder whether in the future I could be left holding empty DAI because governance failed to plan.   Governance need to not just manage the surplus buffer but using all assets (MKR and DAI) to earn return for the DAO to buy things that build a treasury so instead of flopping to fill any DAI shortfall Maker has productive assets to fall back on for borrowing. Wouldn’t the above be a more prudent use of tangible assets than basically using one asset to destroy another? If you had MKR and DAI in your own wallet wouldn’t you be taking that MKR and that DAI and looking for return vs. buying more MKR with the DAI only to ‘burn’ MKR so maybe in the future you could mint more MKR to raise DAI to pay bills?

Executive 11 March 2022 Curve stETH-ETH Onboarding, Rate Limited Flapper, Immunefi Bug Bounty Payouts Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks regular executive. Nice to see the rate limiter going live and hopefully a new onboarding will provide some badly needed increse in revenue.

Polls ending March 17. 2022 Fund Ambassadors Program Pilot Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal secures funding for translation of various material for non-english speakers regarding Maker. While I am a proponent of establishing a marketing strategy before spending significant resources on outreach, this proposal have a very modest ask and is a continuation of an already existing program. All in all I think we need to consider that in many parts of the world the level of english proficiency is fairly low and it is very helpful to have access to material in other languages. Amend MIP64 to clarify critical web bounty amount Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal clear up some language in MIP-64 to clarify critical web bounty amount. I am in favor of making things clearer and thus support this proposal.

Executive 25th of March 2022. Authorizing the ESM on DssFlash and Adding Support for TUSD Implementation Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supporting the current executive is necessary for effective governance. This executive does not contain anything harmful to the protocol and thus deserving of support.

Polls ending on the 28th of March 2022. Ratification Poll for Declaration of Intent - Invest in Short-Term Bonds Voted: Yes Reasoning: With stabelcoins making up an increasingly large share of the DAI supply the need to both reduce counterparty risk and to generate some revenue from these positions increase. This proposal seeks to address the issue. I think the proposal has enough merit to investigate further and use some of our limited bandwith on. With operating expenses starting to meet recurring revenue we must prioritize activities that ensures we are not running at a deficit. Ratification Poll for Facilitators Offboarding (MDS-001) (MIP41c5-SP5) Voted: Abstain Reasoning: With the facilitators of the Core Unit confirming they are stepping down voluntarily after the proposal going on-chain it has lost its relevance. Ratification Poll for GovAlpha Budget 2022-23 (MIP40c3-SP59) Voted: Yes Reasoning: The GovAlpha core unit is perforing an essential function in ensuring that protocol governance is running efficiently and in accordance with previously agreed upon rules. They are also asking for a modest budget to continue their operations. As much as I believe we need to be much more critical of budget proposals going forward, this particular one does not seem to be the first one that needs to be reduced. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget - Real-World Finance (RWF-001) (MIP40c3-SP61) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal caused difficulty in reaching a decision. I am a firm beliver in the potential of real world assets and in the value of bridging the traditional world with crypto. I also believe that having high quality legal assistance on what is the frontier of finance and unexplored legal territory is both necessary and prudent. That being said, the total amount asked for in this budget is very high. It is going to put a considerable strain on the surplus buffer. It also poses a significant risk to the Maker protocol if the core unit decides to not live up to its obligations to MakerDAO. We have seen that offboarding core units doesn’t automatically come with return of excess funding. The deciding factor to me was that in a plausable scenario of rising interest rates and a reduced risk appetite potentially leading to a bear market for crypto, real world assets shows the biggest promise for revenue growth going forward. Nothing in this world comes without risk, and in this particular case I landed just on the side of attempting. I really wish we had scaled back the scope somewhat on the total amount of deals, and rather focused more on a few larger showcases to lay the foundation before committing as much resources as we do. Ratification Poll for Modify GovAlpha Core Unit MKR Budget (MIP40c3-SP60) Voted: Yes Reasoning: As stated above I value the work done by GovAlpha very highly. Giving MKR vesting to two important contributors to the protocol is long overdue and will further align their interests with that of the protocol as a whole. This alignment of incentives is important and as such it is good to see this becoming a standard in all of GovAlpha. Going further I think we need to re-evaluate contributor compensation packages to focus more on MKR staking and less on DAI. Overall a proposal I very much support. Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network - Gelato Network (MIP63c4-SP3) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Keeping a healthy keeper network is important to the protocol and this proposal will allow us to grow it. The costs are very low so overall this seems like a good move. Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network - Keep3r Network (MIP63c4-SP2) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another addition to the keeper network. Much the same reasoning as the proposal directly above. It is also worth noting that increased diversification also increases our redundancy and robustness. Ratification Poll for Rapid Payment for Small Bug Bounties (MIP64, MIP40c3-SP42 Amendment) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal moves the decision of small bug bounty payouts from the protocol level to a core unit. This helps increase efficiency and supports core unit autonomy. It has the added benefit of reducing governance overhead. Unfortunately this comes at the cost of increased risk. It increases the reliance that Immunify will act in good faith and that it will be distribute bounties fairly to the benefit of the protocol. Overall I think the benefits outweigh the risks, but we need to be mindful of the limited options available to the protocol in the event of a core unit failing in its responsibilities. Ratification Poll for Recognized Delegate Compensation (MIP61) Voted: Abstain Reasoning: Due to the obvious conflict of interest in this proposal I abstained the vote. I do think it is worth pointing out that if every delegate did this the proposal would be unable to meet the minimum votes required to pass. This would also be the case with almost every other recent proposal put to a vote including executives. Should the delegates stop voting protocol governance would become significantly less effective and that is without considering the research each delegate puts into their respective votes. In an ideal world there should be some other mechanism with which delegate compensation is discussed and decided. Hopefully this vote can serve as a demonstration of the value delegates brings to this community.

Polls ending 31st of March 2022. Short Ratification Poll for SPF ETHAmsterdam Event (MIP55c3-SP3) Voted: No Reasoning: This proposal seeks funding to host an event at ETHAmsterdam. At the time of the proposal several Core Units have already pre-paid for the same event. This creates a situation where lack of additional funding puts previously committed resources at risk. As such the decision can not be evaluated entirely on its own merit. Supporting such a proposal sets a precedent that core units can gain leverage on an initiative by putting in their own funding first, undermining a regular governance process. That is a precedent I’m reluctant to set. Furthermore I am wary of spending resources on marketing until we have a clear marketing strategy in place. I am a big proponent of increasing our marketing efforts, in fact one of the first things I looked into after starting as a delegate was marketing initiatives. However, marketing has its own science behind it and we should approach it in a professional and deliberate manner. In sum I am therefore not supporting this proposal. Initial Parameters for StarkNet Simple DAI Bridge Voted: Yes Reasoning: Getting into L2s require that we dip our toes. This proposal sets initial parameters with 5M DAI as the limit. Should be big enough to test validity and small enough that if anything goes wrong we’re not too badly burnt. Short Ratification Poll for MIP62 Amendments (MIP4c3-SP2) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal amends MIP62 to account for the offboarding of the Content Production Core Unit. Housekeeping that needs to be done. Investigate Implementation of a Notional Finance D3M Voted: Yes Reasoning: We are experiencing a period of declining revenue and increasing expenses. There are many proposals that wants to increase our spending but few that looks to increasing our revenue. This one is one of them. This poll is for investigating implementation as confirmed by governance and as such should have a low bar for acceptance. I am not sure it’s the best idea that delegates initiates proposals, but as of time of writing we have not implemented a policy on the matter nor made any other decision that it should be disqualifying. In sum I think this proposal has enough merit to warrant a closer look and once that is done do an evaluation on further action.

Executive 01st of April 2022. Core Unit Budget Distributions and Vesting Streams Setup, Gelato Keeper Network Budget Stream Setup Voted: Yes Resoning: Support of the executives remains a fundamental piece of ensuring effective governance. An executive with more content this time and several draws on our surplus buffer. The largest of these were from Real World Assets. This is going to put further strain on our safety margins, but the alternative was to discontinue going in this direction. My expectation is this is going to turn highly profitable for the protocol down the line.

JustinCase:  However, where does that leave MKR holders?   By burning MKR, you incentivize holders to sell the token; companies and DAOs should strive to generate long-term demand for the stock/token, not incentivize investors to purchase and sell to cash out on the profit generated by the entity. When looking at traditional tech companies experiencing rapid growth (i.e. Amazon, Apple, Google, Facebook, etc.), you would be hard-pressed to find any that offer a dividend. The Maker ecosystem and the entire crypto industry are on the verge of unseen levels of growth. With so many exciting opportunities for Maker to deploy capital, it seems irrational to burn profit because we want to provide dividends to MKR holders. Investments made by Maker to progress the ecosystem will create returns far exceeding investors’ cost of capital and will generate greater returns via deployment than burning the token. The aforementioned tech companies chose not to distribute dividends because they believe that they have excellent investment opportunities to deploy capital towards. Maker is in a similar situation and should follow a similar strategy.

Take a look at what Apple has done with share buybacks…not a good example for you.  MKR’s cash flow is nowhere near Apple’s but people do buy and hold businesses with buyback programs and they do very well.  I’ve said this before but reinvesting funds in mkr will be all about trust in the core units and in mkr governance.  If capital is deployed well, then you will get the growth you seek.  But it can also be deployed poorly and wasted.  Anyway, it’s pretty clear that we’re headed toward giving CUs free reign over all profits.  We shall see if the promised growth follows.

No disagreement that capital needs to be deployed appropriately and that investments must achieve returns above Maker’s hurdle rate. A hard stance that MKR should be burned does not seem to be in line with the potential for growth in the ecosystem. Additionally, I would question the extent that Apple’s stock buyback is a return of capital to share holders over a strategic decision to manipulate share related stock metrics.

Correction: I previously indicated that Apple offers no dividend. It offers a quarterly dividend of $0.22. This represents an annual dividend yield, at the time of writing, of .5%. In contrast, comparing the MKR burn rate to a dividend, Maker offers an annual dividend yield of 2.78% (5.6x larger than the dividend offered on Apple stock and down from an all time high of 9.32% on January 22, 2022. Maker will likely have a greater amount of opportunities to deploy capital towards than Apple, yet the dividend amount does not seem to be reflective of this. Burning MKR could be appropriate in some situations, however to take a hard line to always burn the token because we can and believe that there is a 1:1 transfer of value to the token holder seems misguided and rarely true in reality. When comparing the burn rate of MKR to its price, there is very little correlation (if not an inverse relation) between the burn rate and the value of the token. Polls ending 7th of April 2022. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: No Reasoning: I will start by saying I have a lot of respect for the work the Open Market Committee does and in most cases I will follow their recommended proposal. In the current situation however there are two factors that have caused me to go against the proposal. The first being that we are currently in a world of rising interest rates across the board. While that has yet to manifest directly in crypto it is my clear belief this is coming. In a raising rate environment it doesn’t make much sense to lower our own rates. Secondly we have previously shown that we are slow to increase rates when market conditions change, as such I’m reluctant to support yet another reduction in rates. Our revenue is already perilously low, and past rate reductions has not shown a decisive effect on retaining vaults nor increasing them. At the very least we could have waited a little longer before implementing changes. Launch Maker Wormhole With Optimism and Arbitrum Domains Voted: Yes Reasoning: I have become less optimistic on the value proposal of deploying on the various L2s. Even so, it is still too early to consider cancelling exploring growth in that direction. Maker Wormhole will hopefully prove to be a good step in the right direction in making Optimism and Arbitrum an area of profitable expansion for Maker. We must still keep in mind the added risk these deployments entail and how that might restrict other growth opportunities.

Executive 8th of April 2022 MOMC Parameter Changes, CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Debt Ceiling Increase, Recognized Delegate Compensation, ETHAmsterdam Event SPF Funding Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another week another executive. This one contains several items which I voted against. It is going to incur and estimated 6M reduction in revenue from the MOMC parameter changes as well as an additional expense of 50k DAI to the ETHAmsterdam Event. This will reduce our surplus buffer as well as hamper our ability to refill it. Currently the surplus buffer is at the same level it was when we suspended burning on January 23rd more than two months ago. With the proposed changes it is possible and even likely that we will be in a scenario with a diminishing surplus buffer. Even so these are not immediate threats and the community has made their choice. As such I will support this executive and work to try to improve our financial situation. As stated in my delegate platform I will prioritize increasing revenue over cutting costs, but in the current environment cutting costs seems unavoidable. Going forward I will therefore be much more reluctant to support any proposal that increases our expenses without showing a likely increase in revenues that exceeds the increase in expenses in a short to medium time frame. This includes any expansions to Core Unit budgets. .

Poll ending 14th of April 2022. Adjust CRVV1ETHSTETH-A System Parameters Voted: Yes Reasoning: Risk have made a new assessment about CRVV1ETHSTETH-A. In it they recommend an increase in the DC to 50M, and an increase in gap to 10M. Doing so would increase our revenues while keeping us withing acceptable risk parameters. Finding increases in revenue seems rare these days so I am happy to support this proposal.

Executive 15th of April 2022 and out of schedule executive Copy Stub For Out-Of-Schedule Executive Voted: No Reasoning: I warned and in the briefing meeting considering the out of schedule executive. It concerned an urgent security measure. It was employed with no delay so I did not get a chance to vote until it had already passed. Offload TUSD and DAI Transfers Voted: Yes Reasoning: The regularly scheduled executive. Nothing in this executive I didn’t vote in favor for already. Supporting to keep governance running smoothly.

Polls ending 21st of April 2022. Short Ratification Poll to Amend MIP64 to allow more flexibility in scope (MIP4c3-SP3) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal allows Immunify core unit a little more flexibility in determining how to pay out bounties. Passing this proposal will reduce governance overhead while giving up a little bit of control. In my view this falls within Immunify’s mandate and is an area I think is natural for them to have this kind of autonomy. Whitelist Oasis.app on Multiple Oracles (MIP10c9-SP30) Voted: Yes Reasoning: While I do wish we move towards as much premissionlessness as we can, this has been vouched by the Oracles core unit to be useful and as such I support it as a stepping stone forward.

Executive 22nd of April 2022. Voted: Yes Reasoning: This weeks executive contains whitelisting of the oasis app on several oracles as well as replacing the oracle for Curve stETH/ETH. The whitelisting was supported by an onchain poll and the replacement of the oracle was due to a security issue. No imminent danger to the protocol from these changes so I support it.

Polls ending 25th of April 2022 Ratification Poll for Governance Communications Core Unit, COM-001, Mandate Refresh (MIP39c2-SP30) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This updated mandate provides a somewhat increased emphasis on external communication and messaging. While I do think that part is premature before a proper marketing and branding strategy is in place I do think it will be a natural part for govcoms to engage in further down the line. As such an updated mandate makes sense, but the funding for it should be withheld until a more mature time. Ratification Poll for Dissolution of Content Production, MKT-001, Multi-Sig Request (MIP47c3-SP1) Voted: Yes Reasoning: With Content Producion Core Unit off-boarded it doesn’t make any sense to keep this Multi-Sig around. Housekeeping that shouldn’t be very controversial nor work intensive. Ratification Poll for Modify Protocol Engineering Core Unit Budget, PE-001 (MIP40c3-SP68) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Lack of capacity in Protocol Engineering represents one of the biggest bottlenecks for further development of the protocol. Even though this budget like most others represents an increase in spending I’m more comfortable that this spending will result in increased revenues further down the line. Very little of what the protocol attempts to do is possible without some kind of involvement from PE. In light of that and to increase redundancy I think it is prudent to start to consider establishing a PE-002. Ratification Poll for Add Data Insights Core Unit Budget (MIP40c3-SP64) Voted: No Reasoning: Data Insights is a Core Unit that provides data to other core units and to the protocol at large. This budget proposal represents an increase of more than 50%. Having received mixed feedback from the core units already served by DI I do not think this added cost will benefit the protocol. I’m also wary that CUs start express desire to work outside of the protocol. Using services from providers to multiple partners is fine but it is hard to justify a permanent budget from Maker in such a case. Ultimately I think this Core Unit needs to prove its value by vying for business directly from the core units and not from Maker at the protocol level. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, COM-001 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Governance Communications have proposed a new budget that is quite a bit larger from the previous one. I am not thrilled by what seems like inefficiencies in parts of the proposed expenses. A continuation budget should not see this much growth and casts doubts about previous budgets, in particular given that the core unit still has a fair amount of remaining funds. That being said I think GovComms delivers an important service to the protocol and I would not want to put them at risk of being off-boarded at this time. They have also managed to separate their recurring budget from their expanding one which I think is commendable. So considering all factors I land on a very weak yes for this proposal. Ratification Poll for Modify Core Unit Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP63) Voted: No Reasoning: As I wrote in the updated mandate. I do not think this is the right time for GovComs to expand.
