We need to establish a brand and a message to convey before hiring people to start conveying it. Ratification Poll for Adding CES-001 as a Collateral Onboarding Domain Team Voted: Yes Reasoning: In order to remain profitable we need to have effective teams in place to onboard new collatteral. This proposal should help CES increase their effectiveness. Ratification Poll for Modify the Collateral Application Form (MIP6c3-SP2) Voted: Yes Reasoning: As a growing protocol it is natural to review and update various processes. This particular proposal changes the application form for collateral. It is my belief this will ultimately make it easier for counterparties to work with us as it gives more clarity in what we are looking for when we evaluate various collateral. I’m a proponent of less complexity, but that doesn’t mean we can do away with all of it. Ratification Poll for Adding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001) Voted: No Reasoning: As I have stated previously I don’t think we should engage in marketing without a solid plan in place first. This proposal seeks to establish a core unit for events without us having done a proper analysis of whether or not the protocol actually needs to host events or what revenue or other advantage they might generate. Given that onboarding creates both expectations and obligations I’m very reluctant to do so without any confidence this is something that is acutally needed. I do not doubt the ability of this Core Unit to deliver what they promise, there is actually credible track record that they should be able to, but I don’t think it’s the right strategic choice until we have an established marketing and branding strategy in place. Ratification Poll for Methodology and Review Process for Structured Finance Transactions (MIP67) Voted: Yes Reasoning: As with the collateral application above it is natural that we improve other processes. This particular proposal should improve the current process for structured finance transactions. I do expect we will have to come back to this one once we gain more relevant experience, but for now it’s an improvement over what we had. Ratification Poll for Pairwyse Licensure (MIP66) Voted: No Reasoning: Given the current market conditions I do not think fixed-rates is something we should work on. Our backlog is substantial and I think other areas holds more promise for expanding revenues and gaining market shares. In addition this proposal seems expensive for what it does. Ratification Poll for Update Data Insights Core Unit Mandate (MIP39c2-SP31) Voted: No Reasoning: Given the feedback received so far on the work carried out by Data Insight it seems unwise to give them increased responsibilities and mandate. A focus on improving current deliveries should come first or even the creation of a different Core Unit could solve the same issues.

Polls ending 28th of April 2022 Add wstETH-B as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: Giving a wider range of options for one of the most collateral types have been in the works for some time. The running costs of having this vault should be minimal given the reuse of existing oracles. We might even attract some users that didn’t have their needs met by existing vaults and might see some migration from wstETH-A vaults. The only thing I’m not fully in agreement with is the name. Going by the convention of our other vaults this has the profile of a -C vault and I fear it might be confusing for vault users. Extend Strategic Happiness Core Unit (SH-001) Budget Until May Governance Cycle Voted: No Reasoning: I’m a big believer in maintaining core unit autonomy. To get the best results there should not be too much micro management from the protocol level. However with this autonomy comes the obligation of responsibility. Having a failed budget proposal or failing to meet budget proposal deadlines should fall under the responsibility of the core unit in question. It is one way to influence core units to not ask for unreasonable budgets. In addition this particular proposal seem excessive for the time period its intended to cover.

Executive 29th of April 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: The protocol has collectively expressed its will through various polls this week which this executive puts into action. There are several that I opposed getting enacted with this executive. I worry that if we continue the trend of approving proposals that increase our expenses along with those that lowers our revenue we are going to end up in a deficit situation we will be unable to recover from. Even so I don’t see any immediate danger rising from this executive and as such I support it.

Polls ended 2nd May 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - sETH2 (Stakewise Staked ETH) Voted: Yes Reasoning: A greenlight poll for a popular collateral. After reviewing I don’t find any particular reason not to approve this for further examination. Community Greenlight Poll - HVBANK (Huntingdon Valley Bank Loan Syndication Collateral) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Greenlight poll for a proposal that touches into the RWF realm. This one has a few more stumbling blocks than on-chain collateral but I think overall there is enough promise here to warrant a closer look. That being said I think we need to open a wider discussion on prioritization of internal bandwidth. The protocol can only handle a given workload and as such I think it’s wise to become stricter with what goes through the greenlights, at least for a while.

Polls ending 5th of May 2022 Investigate Implementation of a TrueFi D3M Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal will start investigating the possibility of implementing a D3M for TrueFi. This particular D3M will, if implemented, open previously untapped market. I can’t see any showstoppers in this proposal so I approve looking at it more closely. A note on prioritization on greenlights in general: We are currently having a fair amount of greenlight polls. This is of course a good thing, but I’m starting to wonder how many is too many? At some point adding another investigation is going to going to have to wait for a long time until given a more thorough investigation. I’m grateful for the recent clean-up of our pipeline, but I do think we should have a little more critical information to evaluate even at the greenlight stage. For one I think there should be a very rough estimate of expected yearly revenue as well as a very rough estimate of engineering effort required. The process as it is now leaves too much of a backlog and not enough weight to prioritize the effort to the projects which is most strategically for MakerDAO. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: No Reasoning: This is the second time in a row I voted against the recomendations from the Open Market Committee. In general I am very much in favor of following the expert advice from the committee and my negative vote this time is not a firm “no”, but still an overall “no”. My opposition comes from the following 3 axis:  We are currently in a rising rate environment. Even though rates in crypto are going down I am a firm believer this is temporary and they will soon start to follow TradFi rates. The draws on the vaults seems to be much more influenced by general market sentiment than rates. I.E. if people expect crypto to boom they draw more from vaults and vice versa. Maker vaults are more stable and better able to handle large volumes than our competitors. For some vaults (In particular WBTC-B) the discrepancy between stability fee and risk premium is becoming troubling.  Weighing these concerns against the proposal presented I ultimately landed on not supporting the proposal. However going forward I expect to vote in favor of the proposals from the Open Market Committee.

Executive 11th of May 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another executive and this time on a Wednesday. It’ll be interesting to see if this change in timing works out. As usual I support this executive. It does not as far as I’m able to tell contain anything harmful to the protocol even though I did voice dissent to the proposal from the Open Market Committee. The votes however showed that it had support and thus it has my support when it comes to enacting it.

Polls ending 16th of May 2022. Community Greenlight Poll - ATDC (ATD Combustors) Voted: No Reasoning: While the bar to greenlight should be low due to the proposal is going to go through a more thorough investigation the proposed payoff is so low compared to the risk and effort involved that I don’t think it is worth doing. In my view this proposal is within the Clean Money vision and it is with a partner I think will be a welcome one to Maker. This, to me, means we should be willing to go bellow market rates in order to support the vision. However, if we take on excessive risk compared to our revenues our ability to keep supporting the vision will be diminished as we will be more and more limited by keeping capital reserves. Community Greenlight Poll - IPCL (India Power Green Bonds) Voted: No Reasoning: This proposal has the same issues and thus the same reasoning as the previous one. I would like to add that I think both of them have merit and could pass a greenlight. Another issue when viewing both proposals together is the required ad hoc work for both of them. If a more streamlined approach could be found that would increase the attractiveness of both proposals.

Executive 18th of May 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another week another executive. In this particular one I have high hopes tied to the Maker teleport initiative. This also adds a flash loan module and transfers vested MKR to the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling core unit. Hopefully this will further align the motivations of the core unit with other MKR holders.

Polls ending 19th of May 2022. Raise the ESM Minimum Threshold Voted: Yes Reasoning: The emergency shutdown module is an action of last resort in order to prevent the protocol causing harm and to act as a final protection for minority interest holders. There has been some debate about what the correct level should be but I think this quote from LongForWisdom captures the essence of the issue:  “The severity of it being too high is quite low, the severity of it being too low is much, much higher.”  As such I support rising the threshold while we investigate further to what the optimum should be. Adjust the lid Parameter on the Rate Limited Flapper Voted: Yes Reasoning: I pledged to support this change back when we had the larger debate about temporarily halting the burn. This proposal will limit the rate of surplus auctions. This will lead to a situation where we will more gradually burn DAI for MKR in the event of a big spike in the surplus buffer. Typically what happens during a sharp market downturn. This change will still allow us a good rate once we get in a position to burn again. My main objection to this proposal as it stands is the timing. Currently we have an absurdly high SB limit that will take us years to reach under current market conditions. Spending engineering and governance effort on this proposal at this time seems to me to be poor prioritization. If I had not pledged to support this I would have voted against it due to the low optimization. I however strongly believe in commitment and staying true to promises made so I will support this proposal.

Polls ending on the 23rd of May 2022 Ratification Poll for Monetalis Clydesdale, Liquid Bond Strategy & Execution (MIP65) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I pledged to support this proposal last time it was introduced on the condition that it removed the prioritization clause. One of my core values is maintaining obligations and as such I stand by my word. In a wider sense this proposal will allow us to utilize some of the USDC we’re holding for meaningful gains through a partnership with Monetalis. It is my belief that utilizing our stablecoin holdings in order to diversify counterparty risk and to increase revenue is critical in the current market condition and important to the future survival and success of this protocol. Monetalis and @Allan_Pedersen has shown a tremendous patience with our community and a willingness to engage with it. I think we do wisely to recognize the value in that. I also thing we shouldn’t underestimate the importance of urgency. A smaller and more dedicated partner is more likely to prioritize us and to more rapidly accommodate changing needs or requests from the protocol. We should also recognize the potential value of an early partnership as both partners have growth potential. Would I have preferred if they had extensive experience in bond management; yes. But to quote General Patton; “A good plan, violently executed now, is better than a perfect plan next week.” We should have several different bond managers, this is to me a good start. Ratification Poll for Monetalis Lusitano, UK Green Economy SME Wholesale Lending (MIP68) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal was harder to decide upon than MIP-65. I view this proposal as more risky and requiring more work both from us and from Monetalis. Everything I said previously concerning Monetalis still holds true and I doubtful others would still be putting in the effort to work with us after having faced the difficulties they have so far. That commitment has value. The engagement with the community has value. I’m a believer that actions speaks louder than words and Monetalis has shown a willingness to put into action requests presented by us as a community. I do share concerns voiced for team bandwidth and the ability to execute. That being said, I still think we need to at least make an attempt at this. As a delegate and as an MKR holder I have to stress the importance of delivering value within RWA. In a raising rate environment this holds even more promise. I will urge the RWA teams, should they find they find their bandwidth exceeded, to present to the wider community a list of projects to prioritize. Ratification Poll for L2-to-L1 Fast Withdrawals (MIP69) Voted: Yes Reasoning: An easy proposal to support. This one lays groundwork to be able to deploy L2-to-L1 teleports. It’s one more step in our work towards L2s. Ratification Poll for MIP40 Budget Process Amendment (MIP4c2-SP19) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Budgets and reviewing them is one of the most important decision points when it comes to Maker governance. As such I highly welcome more standardization in the field. As long as we don’t use alternative methods to promote fiscal restraint, like competition, direct oversight remains necessary. While this is a step in the right direction I think there should be a future requirement to split any budget proposals into a continuation budget and growth/expansion budgets. Ratification Poll for Strategic Happiness (SH-001) Core Unit Budget Modification (MIP40c3-SP67) Voted: No Resoning: It is always hard to vote against a proposal involving existing core units. In this particular case there is no doubt that @aburban90 has his heart in the right place. That being said, it’s my role to consider whether any proposal is a net gain to the protocol or not. Despite the passion expressed on the forums and in real life we must be able to put some requirements on those who take on certain roles in the DAO. For someone to take on the mantle as facilitator the ability to produce an overview of expenses should be a task that should be manageable and not something that is “80% done”. Furthermore the compensation should match the kind of services provided. The level of compensation has been remarked upon by others than myself, but this endeavor is fairly close to a online merchandising store and shouldn’t have markedly different compensation levels for such an entity despite being associated with Maker. This point rings particularly true in the current economic environment with rapidly declining revenues. There is also the necessity angle to consider. Will this benefit Maker enough to offset the resources put into it? In my view the answer to this is also “no”. I have earlier expressed an unwillingness to put resources into marketing without a clear strategy in place. We are unlikely to see such a plan until at least we have the Brand core unit up and running.

Executive 25th of May 2022 Raise the ESM Minimum Threshold, MKR Vesting, Adjust the lid Parameter on the Rate-limited Flapper Voted: Yes Reasoning: It’s been a while since I was in agreement with everything going into the current executive so that’s a welcome change. I’m not sure I’m sold on the idea of moving the executive to Wednesday as it seems to go into effect the following Monday anyway which just makes the voting and enactment period longer.

JustinCase:  I’m not sure I’m sold on the idea of moving the executive to Wednesday as it seems to go into effect the following Monday anyway which just makes the voting and enactment period longer.   Hi Justin, Thanks for the feedback on the Executive Vote cadence. The past couple of Executive Votes have had office hours turned on so had to wait until Monday after the GSM Pause Delay expired to execute. The current Executive Vote does not have office hours turned on, so would execute on Sunday if passed today, for example.

Polls ending 26th of May 2022 Investigate Implementation of an Antalpha Institutional Vault Voted: Yes Reasoning: I have not been the biggest fan of institutional vaults since I believe that the range of vaults we offer gives a fair range of choices that are balanced by the risk and revenue they bring to the protocol. However, I can recognize the wish for partners and counter parties to get an offering that provides a greater degree of stability. In the future we might look into mechanisms that gives Maker some stability back. This vault, if completed, will add to our existing pipeline of institutional vaults. My expectation is that onboarding these will become easier and easier as we gain experience and hopefully we can get to a point where they are close to fully decentralized. Assuming this vault doesn’t cannibalize existing vaults it will be a welcome addition in a market that has shown a general tendency to reduce their vault exposure. Investigate Deploying the MakerDAO Balance Sheet in ETH Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another investigation poll. With this one I came close to voting no. While I understand the desire to place parts of our reserve into ETH I have some concerns that I hope to see addressed in the following investigation:  Maker is naturally long in ETH. When ETH rises so does value in our vaults and with it our revenues. So far our revenues have been increasing a lot more than the increase in our expenses in ETH. In the event of a need to cover bad debt the price of ETH is most likely depressed. Protecting the protocol is the primary function of the SB and it seems ill advised to put ourselves in a position to have a shrinking SB at the times we need it the most. Deploying the SB into ETH seems to increase centralization of the protocol. There may be some clever ways to do this in a more decentralized manner, but I see at least a slight reduction of decentralization. With this comes increased need for bandwith.  Even so, with the size of our SB and inflation well above 5% we should investigate if there is a way to make sure we at least don’t lose value so I support an investigation but remain sceptical until I see a suggestion for implementation. Launch Maker Teleport with 1 Basis Point Fee Voted: Yes Reasoning: It’s good to see a suggestion that actually starts to generate some revenue from our L2 work. In my view Maker delivers a superior product to our competitors and can thus gain market share despite pricing ourselves equally to our competitors. I also think that it will be a much easier task to remove the cost later in case we need to aggressively gain market share rather than take the reputational hit of putting a price on something that was launched as free.

Poll ending May 30th 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - FEI (Fei USD) Voted: No Reasoning: In the end my core value of simplicity is what decided against this proposal. When you can achieve what the proposal set out to do without going through engineering and governance effort I think it is prudent to go with the simpler solution. In this case it would be perfectly fine to borrow DAI against ETH collateral either through a regular vault or with more effort an institutional vault. The proposal as it stands presents Maker with more risk and more complexity for equivalent revenue. In addition there will be opportunity costs by implementing this over other projects. I don’t see what we would possibly discover after greenlight that would improve the proposal significantly enough to be worth the effort.

Polls ended June 2nd 2022 Offboarding Parameters for UNI-A Offboarding Parameters for UNIV2DAIETH-A Offboarding Parameters for UNIV2WBTCETH-A Offboarding Parameters for UNIV2UNIETH-A Offboarding Parameters for UNIV2WBTCDAI-A Voted: Yes Reasoning: I grouped these together because of their similarity. Sometimes you have to touch ground and realize that something isn’t working out. Sadly that is the case of these vaults where demand simply haven’t materialized. The methodology is similar on all vaults so I approve the start of the offboarding process. Going off my principle of maintaining obligations, I’m happy we got a routine in place following the lessons learned from offboarding Aave. As a consequence I want to stress the paramount importance of clear communication of our intentions to go through with this offboarding in as many different channels as possible. Users need and deserve a warning in advance. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: This votes marks a break my recent trend of voting against the recommendation of the MOMC. The bear market is here and with it a serious unwinding of all types of vaults. The changes suggested are for the large part minor, but one new concept is the signaling of freezing stability fees until September 1st. Given the recent turbulence in crypto and in particular stablecoins lately showing stability can help improve Maker’s market position. With the massive unwinding of vaults any increase in rates will also have a limited impact on short term revenue. Short Ratification Poll for MIP10c7-SP2 - Modify Oracle Data Models Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal changes the Oravle Data Models to more accurately reflect current conditions. As we rely on the data provided from our Oracles these are welcome changes. Periodic reviews of these models comes with the territory of having them. Short Ratification Poll for MIP10c19-SP1 - Update Oracle Expiration Time for All Oracles Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal reduces the overall cost of our Oracles without causing a undue increase in risk. Happy to support this change.

Executive 8th of June 2022 Parameter Changes, Starknet Bridge Limit and Authority Changes, Recognized Delegate Compensation, SH-001 Budget Distribution Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another week another executive, even though it will be two weeks until the next one. Nothing in this that I consider to be dangerous to the protocol so it gets my support.

Executive 15th of June 2022 Temporarily Disable the Aave DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I supported this unscheduled executive that disables the D3M. Initially I voted against the urgent signal request due to the reputational damage and concerns for the wider crypto community. After the previous urgent signal request and executive caused permanent changes to the burn I am also reluctant to accept intentions that it will be temporary. However more arguments were brought forth showing how plausable sequence of events could cause major financial damage to the protocol. In light of that, suspension of the D3M until the next MOMC meeting and then re-evaluate seems acceptable.

Polls ending 16th of June 2022 Deploy a Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation Voted: Yes Reasoning: I have been an outspoken supporter of the burn mechanic since I started as a delegate. This is an issue that has the community divided, but this initiative might provide us with a working compromise. It is also a good chance to test DSSKiln. In my opinion the most important part of burning is showing dedication to the promise of a return of capital to MKR holders. It is integral to the idea of a self running permissionless protocol. Once we put humans into the mix it suddenly becomes a question of trust. Do we trust promises that the burn will ever be put back on? I recently saw a new community member ask about how revenue was beneficial to Maker holders and the answer given, from a CU member, was that there is a buyback and burn system. Here lies the pitch, the story, the promise that not only is Maker burning, but it will keep burning so you will never have to trust a human to buy your MKR from you. Management of Velodrome Airdrop and veNFT Voted: Yes Reasoning: We got these tokens through an airdrop and needed to find a way to make use of them. I’m a little concerned about the added governance overhead, but think we can prioritize if needed. Add rETH as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: This was a decision I had to reconsider. Initially I voted no because we really need to focus our efforts and we have a long backlog. This particular proposal would also get less workload if we could wait until after the merge. Ideally I would have had a “Yes, but later” option. After getting more reassurances from the community that the workload was less than I initially anticipated I flipped from a weak “no” to a weak “yes”. Given the expected revenue, small debt ceiling and the ongoing uncertainty surrounding sETH I still think we should’t put this at the top of our priority, but I do think it will have potential going forward.

Going on vacation This is a public announcement that starting today and for the next week I’ll be away on vacation (back in full action from the 27.). I’ll bring some way to communicate with the outside world, but expect my response time to be lower than usual. These are trying times for us all, and stepping a little back might even provide me with fresh perspectives like we recently got from another delegate returning from vacation.

Polls ending 20th of June 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - KREDIKA (Kredika LTD) Voted: No Resoning: In light of the recent development of the end game plan and the already sizable backlog of collateral I am hesitant to put more into the que. At this time we need to work to reduce complexity of the protocol and we already have two actors covering similar areas as this proposal. Community Greenlight Poll - XSGD (StraitsX) Voted: No Reasoning: The previous comment about collateral backlog also applies to this proposal. In addition taking on a stablecoin against another currency than dollar would add yet another layer of complexity. Furthermore if we do decide to go that route we should go to a more major currency like Euro.

Executive 22th of June MKR Vesting Transfers - June 22 Voted: Yes Reasoning: While this executive transfers a considerable amount of MKR to Deco and to RWF it is within the agreements they have with the protocol. Maintaining our obligations is one of my core values and thus I support this executive. That being said, it does appear that the terms of these agreements may be overly generous and should be reviewed. A final note is an appeal to other @Recognized-Delegates and other MKR voters. At the time of writing this executive have been active for 4 days and so far only 27k MKR supports it. I urge everyone to consider the implications of witholding support as this may lead to ineffective governance and reduce Maker’s reliability as a partner.

Polls ended 27th of June 2022 Ratification Poll for Onboard Growth Task Force (MIP75c3-SP1) Voted: No Reasoning: This specific task force asks for a very broad mandate. It also lacks a clearly defined timeframe. As such it is hard not to view it as introducing a psudo-executive level of governance. This specific group is self-selected and asks for recognition to act on behalf on the protocol with reduced input from MKR holders on specific details and mandate. If passed this would move too much decision-making power from direct input from MKR holders and into the interpretation of this specific group. Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding to IS-001 Voted: No Reasoning: There were a lot of votes that ended on this date and many of them were difficult to reach a decision on. Saying no to the onboarding of a facilitator is painful because I know very well the personal courage and sacrifice one puts in to be weighted by the community. Being a facilitator is a privilege and a great responsibility and we owe it to the community that the ones we appoint have the best possibilities in becoming successes both for themselves and the community. Being a facilitator involves management duties, it involves working with and interacting with other core units, delegates, and other stakeholders. A critical skill in that regard is managing expectations of counterparts. Knowing when to push ahead and when to defer and making sure the team shines and not just individual contributors. A critical skill in that regard is managing expectations of counterparts. Knowing when to push ahead and when to defer and making sure the team shines and not just individual contributors. Taking the assessment received from various members of the community I am not confident enough that Psychonaut is at present in a position to deliver this to Maker and as such I must voice my opposition to appointing him facilitator. Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding to DIN-001 - @tadeo Voted: Yes Reasoning: While I have some reservations with DIN as expressed in the latest budget proposal, my impression of Tadeo is a good one. I hope to see him help DIN evolve into an even better provider of relevant insight for the community as a whole and for CUs in particular. Ratification Poll for Adding Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE-001) Voted: No Reasoning: The week prior to the deadline for voting on I was on vacation and thus I did not cast my vote until late. It’s been one that I have been weighing back and forth for a long time. RWA has been a passion of mine ever since becoming actively involved in the community. My first exposure to LOVE was reading the Sandbox Project at 30.000 feet over Europe on my way to Christmas Holiday last year. Since then, I’ve been watching RWA grow slowly (some might say too slowly) but steadily. Crossing the boundary between TradFi and DeFi carries a lot of work pushing boundaries and it carries risks. Both known and unknown risks. We also operate largely in an unregulated space. With so much capital at stake there is a lot of incentives for actors to act dishonourably, especially so when there is limited legal recourse. It therefore seems prudent to add an additional layer of control to the RWA lending process. The Core Unit cannot be seen in a vacuum, however. A phrase that has been repeated during the discussions have been “review the proposal on its merits”. The process surrounding a proposal and the intentions of the backers of a proposal is part of the merit. I think it is easy to forget that MakerDAO is not a traditional company. There are many checks and balances that we take for granted because we’re so used to operating in a traditional organization. Maker lacks a lot of tools to ensure obedience that is present in most organizations. Firstly, the only real method of sanction Maker has against a CU is the discontinuation of funding. This means that trust plays a much larger role in MakerDAO that one would assume at first glance. Having established that trust in a DAO is already at a premium, it becomes even more paramount when we consider a control function. When an oversight function approves something, it can be because they have done their due diligence, and everything is where it is supposed to be. However, it is also possible that they are not sharing negative findings because they have been incentivised somehow not to. As double checking all the work done by a CU would essentially render them redundant a certain level of trust must exist between the oversight function and the ones employing said function. Having a control function beholden to a subgroup of voting actors casts doubts about the motives of said subgroup. Maybe they are merely concerned MKR holders that wants additional oversight over risky business processes. But it is also possible they have interests they know wouldn’t otherwise be approved by the protocol unless they can exert influence over the oversight. It is also worth taking into consideration that if the process is compromised and funds are lost there are very limited legal recourse to amend the situation. When we add to this the endgame plan and an expressed desire to move away from complex RWA my votes went on no. An oversight CU I can’t fully trust doesn’t have any value. Ratification Poll for Task Forces (MIP75) Voted: No Reasoning: Whenever there exists a power vacuum something or someone will eventually attempt to fill it. Operating and organizing as a DAO is a novel concept and it can be frustrating depending on where in the organization a member might be. It also presents issues to counterparties that are used to dealing with hierarchy and where given individuals are mandated to act and commit the entirety of the organization. Maker does not have an executive level that traditional organizations have, and which would deal with day-to-day coordination and prioritization. As such it is understandable that dealing with approval from MKR holders and having constraints on how quickly it is possible to act that an initiative like this would show up. Even less surprising that it comes from the Core Units which are the ones feeling this need daily. While I recognize the need for the need of MKR holders to clearly state their long-term objectives and priorities it should still be the domain of MKR holders and not left in the hands of the CUs. MKR holders should deal with the “what” and the “why” and CUs should primarily deal with “how”. To pull a parallel to politics. In a representative government you have a civil service that provides the expertise on various fields but ultimately puts into action the ideas and aspirations set forth by the people represented through politicians. In a similar vein. CUs should put into action the vision, objectives and aspirations expressed my MKR holders. Even with limitations on scope and time, this framework seems to sacrifice too much MKR input in the name of efficiency. This is similarly to let the government run itself without input from elected politicians. Thus, I do not support this proposal. Ratification Poll for Adding a Special Purpose Fund - Makershire Hathaway (MIP55c3-SP4) Voted: No Reasoning: The notion of putting existing capital to work gaining revenue is something that aligns very well with my core value of growing the profitability of the protocol it is in this instance in conflict with the values of maintaining obligations and simplicity. For the past year the surplus buffer has been a tiny fraction of the capital in vaults. In fact, last fall there was serious concern that the buffer was way too small when it was down to 1%. Today it is at an all time high of 7,2%. In the same period the size of our vaults has contracted immensely. In isolation this speaks in favour of exposing the buffer for added risk to increase revenue. I have two main arguments of going against. Firstly, even though we are now more comfortably able to cover possible bad debt, we have an added obligation of ongoing expenses to contributors in the protocol. With such reduced revenues it is highly likely we will have to be operation cash negative for an unknown amount of time. As such we must expect the surplus buffer to shrink. Should the markets turn, it will also take time for stability fees to build up enough levels to sustain a new high level of vaults. My second main argument is one of simplicity. By investing parts of the surplus buffer, we are implicitly claiming that the protocol is superior at investing than the MKR holder. If we distributed the capital to the MKR holder, they could then allocate it to whatever risk/reward profile or investment that makes sense to their individual portfolio. We already have a mechanism for this in the burn mechanic and we are also testing out another one with DSS Kiln. Lastly there is the concern about counterparty and centralization risk. This proposal would put a considerable amount of funds under control of a limited number of people in a multisig. There are vectors of attack against this that is hard to eliminate completely. Ratification Poll for MIP16 Amendments (MIP4c2-SP20) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal formalizes the changes to the schedule for deployment of the executive that has been on trial for the past few weeks. The change allows for a little more testing and adds workdays immediately following a new executive. Overall, a change with some upside and little downside. Ratification Poll for Permissionless Open Market Operations (MIP74) Voted: Yes Reasoning: We launched a trial of this MIP to resurrect the burn. This MIP sets a framework for the use of the DSS Kiln to conduct permissionless open market operations. The most immediate is to acquire MKR for DAI from the surplus buffer more efficiently than current flapper auctions. While I can see the argument that having this capacity can incentivize its use in other areas, I believe governance capable of showing restraint and implement whatever direction the community wishes the protocol to go. Having a framework in place reduces the chance of ad-hoc proposals introducing unintended risks. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Strategic Finance Core Unit Budget, SF-001 (MIP40c3-SP69) Voted:  Approve existing budget only (business as usual) Reject Budget  Reasoning: With the recent downturn in revenue, it has become imperative to increase fiscal discipline. A natural first step is to restrict a further increase in our current expenses. Cutting expenses is a much more painful process than not taking them on in the first place. Avoiding increases until we can get a holistic view of total expenses is a prudent and cautious step. Ratification Poll for Onboard/Amend Keep3r Network (MIP63c4-SP4) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal adds a compensation budget for the Keep3r Network. Incentives makes actors do what we want them to. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Growth Core Unit Budget, GRO-001 (MIP40c3-SP70) Voted:  Approve existing budget only (BrandlessGrowth) Reject budget  Reasoning: With the recent downturn in revenue, it has become imperative to increase fiscal discipline. A natural first step is to restrict a further increase in our current expenses. A bear market presents opportunity as well so we should be prepared to deploy resources if there is a fair chance of turning a profit. One area I think we’re woefully unequipped is within marketing. Even so I find it hard to accept that it is not possible to prioritize budgets internally in the Growth CU to realise the Brand CU. Looking to SES they even proposed reducing their own budget to sustain LOVE getting realized. I think it is better to keep a strategic reserve for great opportunities that might present themselves.  The bear market must go on for some time to shake out the most vulnerable actors in the markets before I expect such opportunities will present themselves.
Executive 29th of June 2022. Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks executive. Contents this week is enacting UNI liquidations and transfer of MKR vesting to Risk CU. Governance must move on.

Hello! I just wanted to take the opportunity to say that I appreciate your ability to keep multiple viewpoints and considerations in mind when making decisions… You seem to have a balance and multi-faceted nuance that I find refreshing / largely missing from the larger cryptocurrency community…     JustinCase:  Ratification Poll for Adding Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE-001) Voted: No Reasoning: [This vote has] been one that I have been weighing back and forth for a long time. RWA has been a passion of mine ever since becoming actively involved in the community… Crossing the boundary between TradFi and DeFi carries a lot of work pushing boundaries and it carries risks. Both known and unknown risks. We also operate largely in an unregulated space. With so much capital at stake there is a lot of incentives for actors to act dishonourably, especially so when there is limited legal recourse… When we add to this the endgame plan and an expressed desire to move away from complex RWA my votes went on no. An oversight CU I can’t fully trust doesn’t have any value.       JustinCase:  Ratification Poll for Adding a Special Purpose Fund - Makershire Hathaway (MIP55c3-SP4) Voted: No Reasoning: The notion of putting existing capital to work gaining revenue is something that aligns very well with my core value of growing the profitability of the protocol it is in this instance in conflict with the values of maintaining obligations and simplicity… Lastly there is the concern about counterparty and centralization risk. This proposal would put a considerable amount of funds under control of a limited number of people in a multisig. There are vectors of attack against this that is hard to eliminate completely.   The idea that you’re in favor of growth (via things like RWA) but are willing to temper whatever enthusiasm you have for that objective with your sometimes opposing values of keeping things simple, balancing growth with trustlessness, and an unwillingness to take-on too much risk (for which you seem to have only a low-to-moderate tolerance) shows me that you’re not hyper-focused on RWA “at all cost”, which is really great (IMHO…) To switch gears a bit, I’d like to take this opportunity to engage with you on a potentially difficult/sensitive topic, and I promise that I mean no offense and am making no accusation here: If I’m understanding the data correctly, I see that @rune has delegated the largest portion of his delegated funds to you and @Doo_StableLab equally (12k each, if this delegate address is, in fact, rune’s)… I’m curious to know your thoughts about this (and of course I welcome @rune to share his as well, given that it was/is his choice) and if you’ve addressed this publicly already then please feel free to just point me to that source… I recognize that this large delegation has likely put a bit of a spotlight or whatever on you, and I’ve seen some sentiment in the community that ‘the people rune has delegated to are basically his puppets’ or whatever… I do not assume that stance, and I also appreciate the transparent nature of these delegations (as others, like @MakerMan and @ChrisBlec, have also noted), because it gives us all the chance to address and discuss it… I think I’ve rambled a bit, so to be succinct: Do you feel this is a simply a vote of confidence from the co-founder of the project, that he happens to feel aligned with your outlook and objectives? Or is it more like there’s an implied/implicit pressure to vote how he would want you to on any given issue, and how do you feel about that / how are you handling that? Or perhaps is there even an express understanding that your decisions have been or will be influenced to whatever degree in a more direct way…? Thank you for your time/consideration. My hope is that I’ve communicated effectively, and none of the above feels like an attack/accusation/similar… Just my curiosity as a newcomer, and, p.s. It’s my sincere hope that the ecosystem can find a way, soon soon soon!, to attract much more governance participation from most (as near to all as possible) MKR holders, in order to lower the amount of influence any one party might have over the whole, thus making most of this a moot point anyway…

MakerWOW:  To switch gears a bit, I’d like to take this opportunity to engage with you on a potentially difficult/sensitive topic, and I promise that I mean no offense and am making no accusation here: If I’m understanding the data correctly, I see that @rune has delegated the largest portion of his delegated funds to you and @Doo_Nam equally (12k each, if this delegate address is, in fact, rune’s)… I’m curious to know your thoughts about this (and of course I welcome @rune to share his as well, given that it was/is his choice) and if you’ve addressed this publicly already then please feel free to just point me to that source…   I think this is a very fair question. Delving into it I will answer on my own behalf since I think Doo and Rune should answer concerning their own thoughts and motivations if they are so inclined. My journey as a delegate started back in November last year. If you check my delegate platform you can see that it is the same as it was when I started. My voting history and reasoning for voting is also open for anyone to go through and examine. Doing so I’m certain you will find that I’ve stuck to my core values throughout and I have no intention of changing that anytime soon. Some decisions are easier to make because one side has a clearly stronger case and others are much harder because the arguments on both sides are compelling. You may be aware that for some time Rune has been working on his endgame plan and in May he started to involve the community to a larger extent. I followed the presentations he’s given and after weighing the proposed solution I find that I’m in agreement with the overall direction of the plan. As such I have publicly supported it. So does this mean I’ve given up my own assessments and values? It is my clear impression that the intention of the endgame plan is to have competing views within it. My intention is to do my part to make it the best it can be for the whole of MakerDAO. I do not intend to hide my affiliation with the end-game plan but rather communicate openly as I have done so far. Any delegate serves at the mercy of their delegator. That is as true for me as it is for any other. But that MKR was delegated in the first place because the delegate acted and voted in a way that inspired confidence and trust that they would make good decisions. Thus it is reasonable to assume that any delegator would want that same behaviour to continue. So far as a delegate I have yet to be approaced by a delegator and asked to vote in a certain way. On the other hand I have been approaced by members of CUs and asked to vote in a certain way.     MakerWOW:  Thank you for your time/consideration. My hope is that I’ve communicated effectively, and none of the above feels like an attack/accusation/similar… Just my curiosity as a newcomer, and, p.s. It’s my sincere hope that the ecosystem can find a way, soon soon soon!, to attract much more governance participation from most (as near to all as possible) MKR holders, in order to lower the amount of influence any one party might have over the whole, thus making most of this a moot point anyway…   I’m really happy you took the time to write this post and ask these questions. I’m pretty sure you’ll find that these are issues all delegates ponder on. I’m also certain these are questions that many in the community have but not all are ready to ask. It makes me even more happy to have a newcomer excited enough to deep dive into the forums. I also share your hope that Maker manages to rally more token holders into governance. In my belief we get the best decisions when more voices add to the discussion. Hopefully this answers your questions and if not just let me know and I’ll try to elaborate and clarify.

Poll ending June 30th 2022 Asset Allocation for MIP65 (Clydesdale) Voted: US Short Treasuries (80%) + IG Corp Bond(20%) Reasoning: With USDC growing to record share of DAI supply and revenue dropping to record lows. This proposal promises steps in the right direction for both. This will shift some of our counterparty risk away from USDC. My initial stance was to go 100% for US Treasuries due to the lower risk involved. However, we should not get into a position where we trade one dominant counterpary risk for another. As such it is important that we get exposure to and experience with other entities. Gaining experience with Baillie Gifford will allow us to expand in that direction later. Another reason to accept a little elevated risk is the chance to align more with the clean money initiative. I have high hopes for this proposal. May it come into fruition soon.

Executive 6th of July 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another week another executive. Enacting the proposals that have passed and compensations that are previously agreed upon. Nice to see the number of MKR that support the executive growing.

Polls ending 7th of July 2022 Add RWA-009 (HVBank) as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: With the bear marked fully upon us and current operations deeply in the red, it feels good to vote on a proposal that has the potential to provide the protocol with some much needed revenue. This proposal also allows us to diversify our counter-party risk. I’m excited to see this progress. While it carries other risks, as well as unknown unknowns as this has note been done before, I think they are reasonably minimized. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes It feels good to be friends with MOMC again. I agree with their proposals. Sad to see that Aave D3M keeps being dormant, but at this point it is market considerations. I hope that for the next meeting we will see a discussion surrounding MANA and whether ETH-C vaults can be increased somewhat in SF. There seems to be an ongoing trend where funds get shuffled over to ETH-C for the lower fees and only get put into -A and -B when the market turns down. Select a Target Level of rNPI Profitability to Guide Budget Cuts Voted: 1. Positive (Greather than 5%) 2. Break-even (Plus-minus 5%) Reasoning: The protocol faces several existential threats. One that is looming right now is the slow strangulation unless we manage to balance our revenues and expenses. It is my opinion that there have been a lack of overarching objectives and vision for MakerDAO and as such I think a poll such as this that gives guidance on what to aim for in a comprehensive plan to evaluate expenses seems prudent. I fully expect turning this goal into specific cuts is going to be hard however. My first vote was to keep a profit going. This is directly stated as one of my core values as a delegate. In saying so, I also recognize that doing that with cuts along right now is probably too much to ask. That would entail reducing our expenses by more than 50% and that is going to break our DAO I fear. Luckily we have some projects underway that I expect are going to raise our revenues so the necessary cuts will be more in the order of 20%. Still a significant cut, but one that should be possible to go through with.

Emergency response poll Oh no, this should not be here Voted: Yes Reasoning: Periodically testing the response rate is a sensible way to determine how long it would take the protocol to act in the case of a malicious spell or a governance attack. As long as these tests aren’t done too frequently it provides input to how long we should have delays and can uncover if additional communication channels are required for mandated actors or delegates.

Executive 13th of July 2022 and poll ending 14th of 2022 MOMC Parameter Changes - July 13 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Nothing harmful in this spell. Supported to ensure efficient governance. Add RWA-008 (OFH) as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: This vault represents a historic moment for crypto, DeFi and for Maker. The establishment of this vault signals a bridging of a gap between a large TradFi organization and a DeFi protocol. Two very different organizations from to similar yet very different worlds. Progress tends to come in small steps and sometimes we don’t realize how far we’ve come until we look at the tracks going back from where we came from. This vault should open doors, not only for Maker but also for the wider DeFi space. To remain grounded this vault is still a proof of concept, it has a SF of 0%. It may also be better suited under a MetaDAO down the line. Even so I’m very excited to see this come into fruition.

Poll ending 25th of July 2022 Ratification Poll for Governance Facilitator Onboarding GOV-001 Voted: Yes Reasoning: I’ve gotten familiar with the work of Patrick through numerous calls and with various correspondence on the forum. His work and calm demenour is very well suited to the neutrality that is expected of the governance CU. I wish him the best of luck in carrying on the fine tradition of governance.

Executive 29th of July 2022 Onboarding Real World Asset Vaults Voted: Yes Reasoning: Nothing immediately harmful in this executive. Its back at the old timing window for executives and contains onboarding of Real World Asset Vaults. As these carry promise to improve our revenues in the crypto downturn I’m excited to see them come alive. @Recognized-Delegates At the time of writing it has been 2 days since the executive was ready and we only have 54k MKR supporting it. I kindly urge any recognized delegate that hasn’t voted yet to do so as soon as possible.
It is all about redelegation. Don’t think the exec will pass without it

Poll ending 1st of August 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - bIBTA (Backed Finance Short-Term Bond ETF) Voted: Yes Reasoning: In order to really grow and make a difference I believe it is crucial that crypto breaches the wall into meshing with traditional finance. That way we can enact the positive change we want to see, including realizing the clean money vision. In order to make use of non-crypto native assets they need to somehow get tokenized and made available. The work of “translating” RWA into something manageable is a complex and demanding task. It is one I think Maker is better off letting other entities handle to avoid growing to complex to govern as a DAO. As such I have high hopes this proposal can help pave the road for others of the same type for Maker to interact with. Bonds are a good place to expand into and also fits with the endgame plan. Keeping in mind that this is a greenlight poll and there are many potential pitfalls before this becomes productive I still think the potential here warrants the use of resources to investigate.

Executive 3rd of August 2022 HVBank Drawdown, Keeper Network Stream Re-Deployment Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this week’s executive. Highly excited to see our Huntington Valley bank deal start to come to fruition. I’m a little more apprehensive regarding the returns on the resources we put into the Keeper network but the executive is not the place to withhold support.

Polls ending 4th of August PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: Minor adjustments to various stability fees. While I doubt changing stability fees by 25 basis points are going to have perceptible effect on vault usage, we are now at such low revenue levels that it doesn’t really cost much to try. Honestly I think at this point marketing would have a lot more impact. Crossing my fingers the markets will turn and our revenue and vault usage will increase. Maker Teleport Deployment on Starknet and Associated Risk Parameters¨ Voted: Yes Reasoning: Deploying on L2’s has been a focus of the protocol for a while now. It is nice to see us getting closer to the finishing line. I’m a little disapointed to see the initial parameters set for a 0 bps, when it was previously agreed to be put at 1, but at least there is a process that should be able to correct for this prior to actual launch. While any innovative work carries risk I think the limited debt ceiling we have chosen keeps the risk at acceptable levels. That being said we should work to improve security and lessen risk as we have done on numerous other occasions. Maker has a solid reputation. Let’s keep building on that. Tactical Re-allocation Process for Budget Adjustments Voted: Yes Reasoning: Reducing budgets are never easy. It creates an atmosphere of uncertainty. Contributors naturally will worry about what comes next. At the same time it concerns the survival of the whole. Failure to address the issue will only worsen the problem ultimately leading to a worse situation for more contributors. On the question on whether going for a broad cut or a more targeted approach I was conflicted. A broad cut would presumably mean a quicker process which would be a boon. At the same time different CUs got onboarded in different economic circumstances and it is reasonable to review them holistically. In the end I landed on supporting a targeted approach because it allows the different CUs to have a more involved role in the process and gives us a greater security of not inadvertently underfunding a critical function. My wish is for us to get this process over with as soon as we can so we can turn our attention on focus on the future and the possibilities that lies there.

Executive 12th of August 2022 MOMC Parameter Changes, SocGen Vault Drawdown Authorization, Recognized Delegate Compensation, HVBank Legal Agreement Amendment Voted: Yes Reasoning: A delayed executive due to the unfortunate refusal of Genesis to complete a transaction previously agreed upon. We are operating on the innovative edge of finance so some setbacks are to be expected. It is still disappointing that Genesis refuses the second of four planned transactions. One would imagine that if there were irregularities they would have been discovered and dealt with prior to the first transaction being approved. Even so I expect this to be a minor delay in the grand scheme of things. Another milestone in innovative finance comes with the introduction of the Société Générale vault that comes into effect with this executive. A door opener to even greater things to come. The adjustments from MOMC contains minor adjustments to various stability fees. I deem it unlikely these will impact revenue or vault usage much. Overall an interesting executive without any immediate danger and thus supported.

Poll ending 15th of August 2022 MIP9 Community Greenlight Poll - Pando (Pando Investment Grade Climate Assets) Voted: Yes Reasoning: All the way back in October 2021 the community voted in favor of the Clean Money initiative. As far as I’m aware there hasn’t been a vote to revoke this initiative. It is broad and allows for wide interpretation of what it actually means. Even so the deals we have been closing lately would be hard pressed to fit into the concept of clean money. This proposal however seems to me to fit into the vision of clean money. It is also a greenlight poll and as such the bar should be relatively low. Backing this particular proposal could lead to investments that would help combat climate change. With increasing regulatory pressure, being tied in to positive real world change will also serve to improve our standing in relation to regulators. As such I think we should at least give it a closer examination. That being said, there is rarely a deal that is flawless and I do see several areas of concern with the proposal as presented. Two of the major ones are:   Duration. While it is flattering that Maker is deemed a reliable partner enough that a 14 year facility is sough, it is the longest duration of any asset we’ve been involved with by a long shot. This might not be a complete showstopper, but it needs to be addressed. Especially in relation to secondary markets and how to handle a default scenario. From the preliminary assessments that seems to mean we’re limited to the size of the surplus buffer.  Risk adjusted yields. While I think the clean money vision entails a willingness to give up some financial gain for a given risk level, my view is that Maker should at least be compensated at the level of comparable treasury bonds. As it stands Maker would have to take on elevated risk to receive less than 10-year treasury bonds. This would need to be addressed before I would vote in favor after a more thorough investigation.  Overall I fear that closer examination will reach the conclusion that this proposal is not fitting for Maker at the current time, but if we defer our vision at every opportunity it’s not much of a vision. The debate on this proposal was also long and thorough and revealed a lack of examination to make a final call. While I also recognize that the current state of the RWA CU is not the best I believe this state of affairs to be temporary. Whether this means a reformed CU, some other arrangement or a new meta-DAO remains to be seen.

Poll ending 18th of August 2022 Maker Teleport Deployment on Starknet and Associated Risk Parameters Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal is a follow up to the previous proposal on Starknet deployment. In addition to set the Starknet teleport fee to 1 basis point it sets the deposit limit to 1000 DAI. Setting of fee was agreed upon by the community but was left out in the initial setting of proposals. As a proponent of the basis point fee in the first place it is good to see it make it into the parameters. The deposit limit seems like a reasonable start. Lets test it and evaluate from there.

Executive 24th of August 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: A short executive authorizing the next drawdown of 25M for HVB. Fingers crossed we do not run into any unforseen obstacles with this one. Maintaining our obligations and keeping governance flowing. Polls ending 25th of August 2022 Target Spend Level - August 22, 2022 Voted: 1. 15M 2. 15,5M 3. 16M 4. 16,5M 5. 17M 6. 17,5M Reasoning: In a bear market with declining revenues and increasing costs our hand is forced to take action if we do not want to doom the protocol to uncontrolled decline and potential death. Any of the proposed spend levels constitutes a bellow break even spend level going by the forecast provided by strategic finance. Prior to the uncertainty introduced with the RWA CU I would have had a higher estimate on the income from RWA. As it is view the estimate as being probable. Given the current size of our surpluss buffer, I think we can spending some without causing unacceptable risk. Lower cuts are easier to handle and causes less disruption. A bear market also afords an opportunity to gather talent so we don’t want to make the cuts too deep. Collateral Onboarding Project-based Funding Request (PFR) Voted: Yes Reasoning: A major concern for me with the current state of RWA is ensuring business continuity. This proposal allows for CES to pick up some of the pieces left in the wake of the sudden drop in activity from RWA. Even though this authorizes funds within CES’ own budget I think we should divert some funding from RWA-001 to the various initiatives needed to handle ongoing obligations. While this represents a departure from budgeting norm, we are dealing with a previously unforseen situation. Hopefully it will remain a novel situation and not something we will have to deal with on a regular basis.

Out of sequence. Polls ended 22. of August 2022. Ratification Poll for Modify Dai Foundation Core Unit Budget Voted: 1. Bear scenario 2. Superbear scenario 3. Base case Resoning: I have yet to find anyone argue that we are not in a bear scenario. With the needs to reduce spending we need to examine all CUs and activities. Even so in my mind the superbear scenario cuts too deep, and maintaining our intellectual property rights is an ongoing obligation that we should not take lightly. Ratification Poll for Core Unit Offboarding Process Amendments (MIP4c2-SP15) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Streamlining and codifying the offboarding process was revealed to be important as far back as when Content production got off-boarded. Happy to see further refinement to this work. Ratification Poll for Modify Oracle Core Unit Budget (MIP40c3-SP75) Voted: 1. Approve proposed budget (Reduced budget exempt from further cuts for 12 months) 2. Approve existing budget (Business as usual) Reasoning: In a bear market it is helpful when everyone pitches in and takes responsibility. Oracles were early in proposing voluntary cuts in exchange for guarantees to avoid further cuts for the coming 12 months. Stability is also important to give core units peace to focus on their tasks. As such I find this option to be the optimal compromise. Ratification Poll for MIP50 Direct Deposit Module Amendment (MIP4c2-SP23) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Housekeeping proposal to clear up the language in the MIP50 making it universal. Clarity helps promote simplicity. Easy to support. Ratification Poll for Makershire Redux (MIP76) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is the second attempt at this proposal. The previous time around my two main concerns were volatility in the proposed assets and the manual nature of deployment of capital. This proposal addresses most of my concerns. At least enough to give it an attempt that we can evaluate. Ratification Poll for Offboarding Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I did not support the onboarding of this core unit because I think it is a poor strategic fit. That position has not changed. To me this is a subset of marketing that needs to fit into a marketing strategy which we do not currently have. Even so I’m reluctant to offboard in the middle of an active budget cycle because it is disruptive, obviously to the core unit in question, but also to other core units. As such I refrain from proposing offboardings unless there is clear risk to the protocol or the costs incurred is substantial. Once a proposal is presented however that uncertainty is already introduced.

Polls ending 29th of August 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - RWA Arranger (BlockTower Credit) Voted: Yes Resoning: With the current lack of an operational RWA team and with the situation unlikely to be remedied in the short term it is difficult to approve any new applications for real world assets. This particular proposal is for the role of arranger which I believe to more likely to fit the emerging landscape of meta-DAOs and the endgame plan. Even so I think we must be prepared for a longer than usual process. Community Greenlight Poll - Cabot (Cabot Renewable Energy Crypto Mining LLC Voted: No Reasoning: In the current transition period and with a lack of a functioning RWA team for the short term, I think it creates false expectations to greenlight this application at the current time. Community Greenlight Poll - DDC (Detox Digital Coin) Voted: No Reasoning:  In the current transition period and with a lack of a functioning RWA team for the short term, I think it creates false expectations to greenlight this application at the current time. Executive 31st of August 2022. HVBank Drawdown, Maker Teleport Launch on Optimism and Arbitrum Voted: Yes Reasoning: Nothing objectionable in this executive. Happy to see HVBank finalized as well as the launch of Teleport on Optimism and Arbitrum. Fingers crossed for smooth sailing. Polls ending 1st of September 2022. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: 1. Option 1 2. Option 2 Reasoning: Another open market committee another reduction in stability fees. This proposal gives the option between minor cuts and moderate cuts in an effort to increase vault usage. Previously there have been little visible correlation between rate and usage, but there might be signs this is turning. Personally I think it is too early to try the heavier cuts in fees. I would much rather see us try to reduce CRs first. Maker is different from other lending providers that we can provide much greater liquidity than others without affecting fees. As such I expect the players utilizing Maker to be more incentivized by lower CRs than slightly lower fees. And as always macro considerations reigns supreme, so regardless of our actions the main driver will be the markets belief in the value of leveraged collateral. Ratification Poll for Legal Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral (bIBTA) Special Purpose Fund (MIP55c3-SP6) Voted: Yes Reasoning: With the sudden reduction in output from our RWA core unit a need for business continuation has been created. I have previously supported CES in continuing some of the work and this is a request to carry on other aspects of the work. Maintaining our obligations is a key virtue to me as a delegate and thus I support this proposal. My natural expectation is that this is going to be covered by a similar reduction in the RWA-001 budget.

Polls ending 5th of September 2022. Short Ratification Poll for Legal Work on MIP65 Special Purpose Fund (MIP55c3-SP8) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is another proposal in response to the failure of RWA-001 to deliver on their mandate. This particular one provides funding for legal work being carried out by Christian Pedersen and done under the umbrella of the Strategic Finance core unit. Immediate business continuity must be preserved while we organize a long term solution to how we treat real world assets. Short Ratification Poll for MIP65 Amendments (MIP4c3-SP4) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another proposal in response to the failure of RWA-001 to deliver on their mandate. This particular amends wording in MIP-65 so that it no longer requires the certification of the RWA-001 facilitator. A sensible course of action since at the present time it seems unlikely that RWA-001 will resume operations. MKR Pro-Rata Vesting for former RWF-001 Members Voted: No Reasoning: This one was difficult. Maintaining obligations is a core value of mine. Rewarding contributors according to agreements are important to me. In this case however, the contributors in question does not meet the criteria for payment according to the agreement. There are valid arguments why it would be possible to make an exception. I made a post explaining more in detail here. In the end I came down in favour of preserving the cliff as a concept. A precedent here will open the floodgates. An almost immediate example before this proposal has even passed can be seen here. Updating HVBank (RWA-009) Legal Agreements Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal updates the legal agreements with HVBank. There are numerous changes but the majority clarifies and specifies more detailed some of terms and conditions of the agreement the most important being the scope and types of loans being acceptable. This will remove any confusion as to what the agreement is actually about since some of these terms were not clearly stated before. Executive 7th of September 2022 Core Unit MKR Vesting, Recognized Delegate Compensation, MOMC Parameter Changes Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another executive. This one contains CU MKR vesting, MOMC parameter changes and delegate compensation. My fingers are crossed changed MOMC parameters results in increased vault usage. We could really need it at this point given that our revenue from vaults are at their lowest point in 2 years.

Executive 14th of September 2022. Core Unit Budget Streams, SPF Funding, HVBank Legal Update, MKR Stream Accounting Cleanup Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks executive. Enacting accepted proposals are required to continuously improve the protocol. No immediate dangers, even if it got a little delayed due to waiting for final confirmation on the validity of the spell. Polls ending 19th of September 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - GUNIV3-BUSD-DAI Voted: No Reasoning: I went back and forth on this one, but ultimately ended on “no” because I don’t think the expenditure of resources on this proposal is worth it at the current time. The liquidity is limited and while I think this proposal might have merit in a more medium term I think we are better served by focusing our resources elsewhere in the short term. Community Greenlight Poll - GAMMA UNI-V3-WBTC-RENBTC (Gamma Uniswap v3 wBTC-renBTC) Voted: No Reasoning: Reviewing this proposal in light of the assessment given by risk and the estimated revenue this proposal seems to be too risk heavy for the rewards offered. I don’t think this is likely to change withing a reasonable time frame. As such we are better served examining other collateral. Community Greenlight Poll - GNO (GnosisDAO) Voted: Yes Reasoning: The mint promised in this proposal is substantial. We do need to examine more new on chain collateral to diversify our risk and to avoid stagnation. Even with a stricter expectation for success my assessment is that this particular collateral is worth investigating further.

Polls ending on the 26th of September 2022 Ratification Poll for Amend Measurement Period For Delegate Participation Metrics (MIP4c2-SP24) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I came very close to voting “Abstain” since this MIP very easily falls into a conflict of interest as a delegate. In the end I came down on supporting because it provides a more timely response to a delegate failing to meet the duties required. With the current way we track performance metrics a delegate could build a perfect record and then stop all voting and communication for over a month and still receive compensation. Shortening the measured period reduces the potential time for a free ride. Ratification Poll for the MakerDAO Delegates MIP Set Voted: Abstain Reasoning: Due to the extremely obvious conflict of interest of deciding on your own compensation I abstained this vote as I have done in other votes concerning delegate compensation. I really wish there was a functioning alternative to deciding questions related to delegate functions or compensation. Ratification Poll for MKR Compensation for StarkNet Engineering Core Unit, SNE-001 (MIP40c3-SP79) Voted: No Reasoning: I want to start this by saying I do think StarkNet deserves MKR compensation in the current compensation environment and I could very well support an alternative proposal. There are several reasons why I’m opposed to this particular proposal. Firstly I think the overall compensation is very high, in fact it slightly exceeds that of Protocol Engineering (249/FTE vs 270/FTE), this is despite StarkNet currently holding a more limited scope of responsibility and also a significant smaller impact on the health of the protocol. Secondly I do not agree to starting the cliff period at the inception of the Core Unit. The whole point of the cliff is to ensure aligned incentives and a shared concern for risk to the protocol. This is significantly diminished by almost eliminating the whole of the cliff period. Thirdly I think that we need to examine MKR vests in general. Of the distributed MKR a dissapointingly low portion have been kept by contributors, meaning it would make sense to look at alternative forms for compensation that do not negatively impact existing MKR token holders value. Since we need to honor existing commitments I think it is prudent to be extra careful to enter into new agreements that we will have to honor for years to come. Ratification Poll for Special Purpose Fund for The Ambassador Program (MIP55c3-SP7) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I belive in the idea of banking the bankless. The major areas to do so does not neccesarily use English as their primary language. Recent events have shown a growing support for crypto in South America and especially in Argentina. To help make us more accessible I think the ambassador program is a good step. Ratification Poll for Modify GovAlpha Core Unit MKR Budget (MIP40c3-SP80) Voted:  150% 100%  Reasoning: While my general apprehension against MKR vesting in its current form also applies to this proposal, in the end I reach the opposite conclusion. This proposal has a much lower MKR/FTE, it is also previously approved through MKR governance meaning we have an obligation to see it through. Ratification Poll for Strategic Happiness Core Unit (SH-001) Offboarding (MIP39c3-SP2) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I do not think the Strategic Happiness Core unit is a good strategic fit for MakerDAO. I did not think this when it was first proposed and I have not changed my mind from seeing it in operation. With the downturn in revenue since its inception and thus the expenses it incurs be an ever growing proportion of those revenues it is also increasingly difficult to justify the level of spending. Adding marketing activities with no overall plan on what we attempt to achieve is also very unlikely to generate value in excess of expenses. I have seen the argument to delay approving this proposal due to another similar proposal coming up in the next governance cycle. In the final analysis there can be no certainty on the outcome of a hypothetical next proposal. As such I must vote the way I think best for the protocol on every proposal. And that to me is for SHCU and Maker to part ways.

Executive the 28th of September 2022. Update the PROXY_ACTIONS_END_CROPPER Address, Starknet Bridge Deposit Limit Increase, Core Unit MKR Vesting Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks executive to keep governance flowing. Polls ending 29th of September 2022. Update rETH Onboarding Parameters Voted: Yes Reasoning: Given the time passed since this collateral was first proposed onboarded and the developmens that has happened it seems reasonable to update the parameters to more closely reflect actuality. Collateral Auction Parameter Updates Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal from Risk adjusts some of the auction parameters to better align to current conditions. The changes seems reasonable and it is to be expected that we need to adjust to changing market conditions. Poll ending 3rd of October 2022. Community Greenlight Poll - RFA (RFA - Canadian Federally Regulated Mortgage Originator) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I’m generally reluctant to recommend any greenlight poll given the unfortunate state of our ability to handle them in the short term. Even so this specific proposal shows promise as well as a diversification compared to other onboarded collateral. Looking into the crystal ball I foresee this particular collateral being more suited to a metaDAO than to the core. Time and investigation will show where it ends up.

Executive 5th of October 2022 Monetalis Clydesdale (RWA007-A) Onboarding, Funding Ambassador Program SPF, Core Unit MKR Streams and Transfers Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks executive. Happy to see that our Monetalis deal start to get traction in more traditional media too. This helps build both presence and legitimacy. If we are to succeed with broader adoption we cannot remain unknown to masses of people. Polls ending 6th of October 2022. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: This particular proposal have insignificant impact on our revenue but includes the tightening of one debt ceiling to reduce risk exposure. My default stance is to support our appointed committee and I don’t find anything objectionable in this proposal. With the parameter guidance it should be noted that no increases in our major vaults are planned for the remainder of Q4. This means that we must expect our revenue from crypto collateral to be well under our running expenses. As such we must put further faith in RWA or other forms of generated revenue to keep us afloat until market conditions improve. This must be part of our overall picture even as we presumably start to implement the endgame plan. Especially as we stay in pigeon stance the importance of RWA in the short term remain substantial and needs support going forward. The alternative is to slowly bleed surplus buffer and maybe survive. Approve Multisig for Management of Velodrome NFT Voted: Yes Reasoning: In any governance process we need to strike a balance between efficiency and security. Any multisig carries a risk for abuse.
