The greater value that can be extracted with the particular sig, the greater this risk becomes. Looking at the overall value involved and the reputation risk and financial incentives for the potential signers the overall assessment comes down on “approve” for this particular proposal. That being said, any of our multisigs should be routinely reviewed to ensure the risk/reward equation have not meaningfully been altered since approval. Poll ending 17th of October 2022 Community Greenlight Poll - ANCHORAGE (Anchorage Lending Crypto Mining) Voted: No Reasoning: While the lack of a functioning RWA team doesn’t mean I categorically vote against any greenlight proposal it does mean my bar for approving is significantly higher than it otherwise would be. This particular proposal carries a high degree of necessary due diligence. As such I do not think it is a good strategic fit for Maker at this time.

Polls ending 13th of October 2022 Whitelist Oasis.app on rETHUSD Oracle (MIP10c9-SP31) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Hardly a controversial proposal, this will make it easier for our close partners by giving them access to our oracles. I think the future of DeFi entails collaberation and maintaining and expanding our relationships will make us stronger going forward. Change PSM-GUSD-A Parameters Voted: Yes Reasoning: While I’m uncertain this will increase our revenue in a meaningful way, at least it is worth the attempt. Diversifying our stablecoin exposure from an overwhelming portion of USDC this is also a step in the right direction though it exposes us to some of the same kinds of problems just from a different actor. Going a bit back and forth I ended up on at slight yes. Best to monitor the development and then reassess. End DAI Funding For Sourcecred Voted: Yes Reasoning: This one was hard to approve. I wrote a line of argument against this proposal here. Even so I think in the final analysis the overall cost to GovAlpha (not just financial, but also workload) the benefits are just too minor. Hopefully a replacement system that can reward contributors starting out can be found. MOMC Guidance - Remove ETH Supply Yield And Liquidity Incentives From D3M Target Borrow Rate Calculations Voted: Yes Reasoning: I concur with the analysis presented that the additional risks a user is exposed to on Aave and Compound justifies a higher reward for using them. As such I also agree that it is reasonable to exclude those rewards in our calculations. MOMC Guidance - Allowed Spread Between D3M Target Borrow Rate And ETH-A Stability Fee Voted: 0,5% (0%) Reasoning: Assuming a change to the previous poll is passed which seems highly likely it makes sense to adjust the spread to account for the change. A spread of 0,5% seems to provide a good balance between exposure and revenue. Furthermore it keeps the total exposure closer to our current surplus buffer. Executive 14th of October Collateral Auction Parameter Changes, MOMC Parameter Adjustments, Recognized Delegate Compensation for September Voted: Yes Reasoning: As usual I supported the current executive. The spice must flow.

Polls ending 24th of October 2022 Ratification Poll for Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set Voted: Yes Reasoning: Finally the big moment. Even before I attended the first DVC back in May it was clear that reform was needed at MakerDAO. The scope and complexity had grown substantially and was already making governance and oversight hard to manage. Since then the endgame plan has evolved. From my personal perspective I think this plan provides a foundation and a direction upon which to build. The devil will continue to be in the details and much must be done before even the first parts of this plan will bear fruits. I’m particularly hopeful that changes to the front end of governance and the gamefication and staking rewards will succeed in bringing in more smaller MKR holders and creating a lasting interest in Maker governance. At the same time, I fear the tokenomics is the weakest link in this plan so far. Ratification Poll for Offboarding the Strategic Happiness Core Unit - SH-001 (MIP39c3-SP3) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I’ve been an opponent of the SH core unit since its inception. The strategic fit was bad due to a lack of coordination of marketing efforts, and the downturn in revenue has made the expenditure even more ill advised. Even in sync with other marketing effort it does not make any sense as its own core unit. Ratification Poll for Offboarding the Events Core Unit - EVENTS-001 (MIP39c3-SP4) Voted: Yes Reasoning: My reasoning today is the same as it has been since the first vote. I do not think we should add marketing efforts piecemeal and without a solid set of objectives what we are trying to achieve and as part of an overall marketing strategy. Ratification Poll for Offboarding the Real-World Finance Core Unit - RWF-001 (MIP39c3-SP5) Voted: Yes Reasoning: I’m sad to see RWF go as it was a pioneer in Maker history. However it is a necessary step on the road to changing how we approach real world assets. To me real world assets provides a crucial link that is required if Maker is truly going to make a difference in the world. Regardless whether the goal is the clean money vision or if it is to bring banking to the bankless we must somehow pierce the veil between crypto and real world goods and services. Ratification Poll for Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards (MIP81) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Maker is in a dangerous situation where we need to grow out revenues. One fairly untapped source is putting our balance sheet to work. This provides an opportunity to do so. Although the proposal carries risks, it is my belief that technical solutions can mitigate the most serious ones. Ratification Poll for Monetalis-Coinbase Appaloosa (MIP82) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another proposal to put our balance sheet to work. I’m happy we are taking our time implementing these and making sure we don’t stumble on the execution. Loss of our capital should be our primary concern at this stage, even tough I’m confident we can make it work. Ratification Poll for Legal And Commercial Risk Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral BlockTower Credit - RWA Arranger SPF (MIP55c3-SP9) Voted: Yes Reasoning: An easy proposal to support. We want to examine this collateral and we can’t do that without the resources necessary. Ratification Poll for Facilitator Offboarding Process (MIP41c5) adjustments (MIP4c2-SP26) Voted: Yes Reasoning: With the sweeping changes that are coming up on the protocol this amendment might become redunant but even so I think it constitutes an improvement over what we have today so I support it. Ratification Poll for Facilitator Offboarding - RWF-001 (MIP41c5-SP12) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Given that I was co-author on this proposal it would be strange not to support it. In order to proceed with the new approach to real world assets we need to clear out old mandates and actors. Executive 26th of October 2022 rETH Technical Onboarding, Enable Starknet DAI Bridge Fees Voted: Yes Reaoning: Supported this weeks proposal as ususal. Poll ending 27th of October 2022 MIP65 Asset Reallocation Voted: Yes Reasoning: A sensible proposal that lowers the risk while maintaining the majority of the revenue. As I wrote earlier our main concern should be to preserve the capital employed and that means low risk and in all likelihood low yield.

Executive 2nd of November 2022 Budget Stream Housekeeping For Offboarded Core Units, Oracle Whitelist Addition, SPF Funding Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks executive as usual. Changes must be enacted to make a difference. Polls ending 3rd of November 2022 Activate Liquidations for Stablecoin Vaults to Clear Bad Debt Voted: Yes Reasoning: The vaults in questions predates the PSM. The way our system is now set up these vaults are accruing stability fees that is in excess of what we will be able to claim for them. Liquidating these vaults will seemingly incur losses, but it is mostly a question of setting the record straight. With all the recent proposals for utilization of the PSM moving some additional USDC there doesn’t seem to be the worst idea. One Month Budget Extension for Strategic Happiness Core Unit Voted: No Reasoning: When a decision is made to offboard a core unit we cannot in good conscience keep extending the lenght of the offboarding. This particular core unit has already gotten extended once to be able to cover Bogota and have been given a generous severance package. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported the proposal from the open market committee. Minor changes this time. With rates rapidly rising in traditional finance I expect to see some contagion into DeFi as time marches on. Still the majority of lending demand seems to originate in expectation of rising asset prices so we will probably not see substantial increases until the next bull cycle. Until then we will have to make do.

Executive 9th of November 2022 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Another week another executive needed to enact approved changes. Nothing immediately damaging here so supported. Poll ending 10th of November 2022 Add the Compound V2 DAI Direct Deposit Module (D3M) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Activating the Compound Direct Deposit Module will lead to some badly needed revenue for the protocol. As a risk mitigating measure the debt ceiling will start off low and increase with time. Any issues should be dealt with as early as possible to keep the capital at risk low. In order to scale we need to minimize the amount of human input and this provides another automated solution. Urgent Executive 12th of November 2022 Urgent Collateral Parameter Changes Voted: Yes Reasoning: This urgent executive follows an urgent signal request to sharply change the parameters of the MANA vault in order to encourage discontinuation of its use. The intention is to protect the protocol from bad debt as the risk assessment has rapidly deteriorated. This is very sensible from a risk management perspective in isolation. It has been known for some time that MANA has been an asset with high slippage. However I think we need to consider other aspects and learn from this going forward. It is clear that it is Maker’s right to change parameters according to changing market conditions. However we do need to be mindful about the impact of those changes on our users and how well we can communicate with those users. Even though we have the right to change the parameters the rate and magnitude of that change cannot be infinite. I don’t think anyone would accept if we overnight increased SF to 1.000.000%. Similarly a change to liquidation penalty to 100% would be unreasonable. As such we should put a limit to the potential magnitude and rate of change of our parameters to give a certain amount of predictability to our users. The less communication we have with the end user the lower the rate of change should be. These considerations should go into the work MOMC does.

Polls ending 24th of November 2022 Add GNO (GnosisDAO) as a new Vault Type Voted: Yes Reasoning: Adding GNO as a new Vault type carries a risk. There is limited liquidity other risk factors covered in the risk analysis. As a whole they don’t seem overly risky. With the way the markets are shaking out and the looming crypto winter I believe it is important to forge alliances. No one protocol can do all the work alone. In the specific case of Gnosis we also have an agreement with them. In order to maintain a reputation as a reliable partner I think the agreement weighs more heavily than the slightly elevated risk. Thus I support this proposal. Add Multiple BlockTower Credit Vault Types (RWA010, RWA011, RWA012, RWA013) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal seeks to onboard senior secured debt using DAI. The estimated yield is at 4%. Maker is still in a precarious situation when it comes to revenue compared to expenses. This proposal would mean we can shift the balance somewhat at the same time as we get to diversify our exposure. Given the type of assets being proposed the risk should be manageable. We need to start to monitor our USDC reserves as we are getting more proposals for its use than we can realistically employ. The relatively low debt ceiling on this proposal compared to others while giving us a chance to build relations as well as gain experience seems to me to be an overall valuable package. Offboarding Parameters for renBTC-A Voted: Yes Reasoning: Given the recent events, offboarding renBTC seems the prudent measure. Maker has already closed the possibility of taking on more debt to this collateral. These further changes to parameters will assist in closing down existing positions. Sad that we need to. Hopefully better times will come. Proceed with Pre-Implementation Work for the Deal Outlined in MIP90 (BlockTower Liquid AAA Structured Credit and Money Market Fund) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This poll asks for sentiment for expending work to assess the viability of onboarding another highly rated bond asset. This type of collateral seems to be the best fit to diversify our PSM exposure until we can get negotiated revenue sharing arrangements with PSM partners. In this environment of medium and rising rates this is likely to generate a meaningful yield for Maker as well. At the very least it is worth investigating.

Polls ending 28th of November 2022. Ratification Poll for Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Facilitator Onboarding (MIP41c4-SP38) Voted: No Reasoning: With the approval of the framework for the endgame plan it is time to start to pivot the organization toward this new direction. That means we have to shape existing core units into the scopes, metaDAOs and ecosystem actors. In my view Immunify represents a clear ecosystem actor. As such it should use the remaining budget to reorganize and seek funding through other parts of the organization. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Development and UX Core Unit (DUX-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP82) Voted: 1. Approve Reduced budget - New Base 2. Approve existing budget only Reasoning: Again the change of strategic direction towards the endgame necessitates changes to the current and future tasks. DUX will play a crucial role in building the new front-end that will be an integral part of the endgame. As such their workload is likely to increase or at the very least remain constant. In a project as complex as the endgame it would be very fortuitous if we do not run into any unforeseen issues and additional workforce can help mitigate delays. Ratification Poll for CoinShares Active Treasury Management (MIP86) Voted: No Reasoning: This proposal was a close “no” in my final estimation. There is a lot to like about it. It creates much needed revenue for Maker, it is in very solid financial products, and the team has made a good case for the proposal. Yet there are some factors that in the end turned this from a “yes” to a “no” for me. First, it goes against my core value of simplicity. Deploying the PSM needs to be done into very secure facilities. This proposal introduces a layer of management and thus complexity that goes against the notion of decentralization and automation. Secondly, Maker’s PSM reserves have been substantially from earlier levels. Thus Maker also needs to factor in how much time it will take to be able to meet the obligations to repay USDC. Hopefully we can find a future more automated and decentralized solution to be able to get exposure to these types of yields. Ratification Poll for OUSD Decentralized Rewards (MIP87) Voted: No Reasoning: While I can see the value proposition of this proposal I find it hard to reconcile with Maker’s risk tolerance. The limited liquidity coupled with an active management strategy makes this a poor strategic fit for Maker in my evaluation. Unless there is a fairly major shift in sentiment I do not see that changing either. Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Mandate (MIP39c2-SP38) Voted: No Reasoning: As I do not see a future where Immunifi remains as a core unit I do not see any reason to modify the mandate. As an ecosystem actor Immunifi is free to determine their own and do not need any further approval from Maker. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security (IS-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP83) Voted: Reject Budget Reasoning: As previously argued, I believe the future of Immunify lies as an ecosystem actor in the endgame paradigm. By that logic it doesn’t make sense to renew the current budget. The remaining funding should rather be used to pivot as quickly as possible. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Governance Communications Core Unit DAI Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP84) Voted: Reject Budget Reasoning: Evaluating the endgame plan there is unfortunately no room for a Gov-Coms core unit. Given that the budget is only six months and the time line for the end game plan is a year I was close to voting in favor of this budget proposal. In the end I believe it is in the overall interest of the protocol to enact these changes without delay and that Gov-Coms can transition into an ecosystem actor. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit DAI Budget, SAS-001 (MIP40c3-SP85) Voted: Reject Budget Reasoning: With the change into the end-game plan I do not see Sidestream Auction Services continue as a core unit. As with numerous other core units the future lies as an ecosystem actor. In order to expedite the change it thus seems sensible not to renew the budget and lock in the core unit structure for another budget cycle. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify TechOps Core Unit DAI Budget, TECH-001 (MIP40c3-SP86) Voted: Reject Budget Reasoning: Tech Ops is another core unit that doesn’t fit into the endgame plan in its current form. In many ways Tech Ops are already taken steps towards becoming an ecosystem actor and I think it is very possible to fund these kinds of services indirectly through MetaDAOs or the scopes. As with any transition there will be some friction but I believe a faster change will ultimately lead to less reduction in efficiency overall. Ratification Poll for Modify Emulated Surplus Buffer Upper Limit (MIP84c10-SP1) Voted: No Reasoning: It is unclear to this delegate where the number 1BN is taken from. The last time the protocol added an arbitrary number to the ceiling of the surplus buffer of 250M it stayed. Until there is a more well argued reason for a given parameter I think it is prudent to refrain from setting one. Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Redwood Friesian (MIP88) Voted: No Reasoning: Monetalis has a track record of providing Maker with a steady stream of opportunities to limit our USDC counterparty exposure. This proposal seeks to do so by providing access to low risk real estate lending. While the risks remain low they are still in excess of what can be expected from high grade government bonds. Our tolerance for losses to bad debt remains very limited given the size of our surplus buffer and thus I think Maker should choose the safer path and refrain from this particular proposal. Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Arrow Andalusian (MIP89) Voted: Yes Reasoning: While much of the same reasoning for MIP88 also holds water for MIP89, there is an agreed upon strategic direction with the clean money vision. It would thus seem that placements that are in support of that vision can endure somewhat worse terms than would otherwise be acceptable. In this particular case the risk is higher than it could otherwise have been for the same level of revenue. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit DAI Budget, SES-001 (MIP40c3-SP87) Voted: Approve speedy operations platform options budget Reasoning: SES has through this proposal put forth a plan for the transition of the core unit into a form compatible with the endgame plan. In order to minimize the transition period the budget requested for the fastest completion seems sensible.

Polls ending 01st of December 2022 DAI Savings Rate Adjustment Voted: Leave the DSR unchanged at 0.01% Reasoning: In a world with continiously raising rates, even if the pace might be slowing, it is highly likely we’ll see a harmonization between real life rates and rates offered in crypto. As such it is my belief that if Maker wants to retain the amount of DAI in circulation the Dai Savings Rate will have to increase. As such I believe the reasoning behind this proposal is sound. There are however two reasons to vote against it at the present time. Firstly, this is likely to provide another expense to the protocol. This expense will also come from assets on our balance sheet that haven’t been proven to provide revenue at the present time. In particular this is the case for the various PSMs. While I do think it is very probable that these will provide a steady revenue stream I think it would be prudent to have seen a proven stream and to have had more time to avoid unknown unknowns. Secondly, even with a increase to 1% on the DRS I’m unconvinced it will create too much of a positive impression amongst DAI users, but it will expose us to negative sentiment if we have to lower the rate again. This is also primarily a question of timing. My preferred solution would be to wait until January/February to consider such a change. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: The open market committee has once again delivered proposed changes. The changes proposed seems reasonable and in line with the strategic direction Maker is moving. As such I am supporting this proposal. Undertake Necessary Risk and Legal Assessments to Increase the NS-DROP Debt Ceiling to 50 Million DAI Voted: Yes Reasoning: New Silver has been one of MakerDAOs longest running partners. It is good to see them being in a position where they wish to expand upon this partnership. A proven track record as a reliable partner should not be underestimated and should be valued even more in a world where we see various projects fail every month. Even so we should not blindly rely on trust and it therefore seems prudent to invest in additional risk and legal assessment before committing to providing a higher debt ceiling. Executive 02nd of December 2022 Compound D3M Onboarding, Activating Stablecoin Liquidations, Oracle Feed Whitelisting, Starknet Relay Upgrade, and MKR Vesting Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks executive in order to enact previously agreed upon changes to the protocol.

Executive 9th of December 2022. Recognized Delegate Compensation, GNO Onboarding, BlockTower Credit RWA Vaults Onboarding, renBTC Offboarding, MKR Vesting, MOMC Parameter Changes, DAI Savings Rate Adjustment, Starknet Bridge Parameter Changes Voted: Yes Reasoning: A substantial executive. Even so the changes have been approved in various forms through the governance process. I am unable to find anything that poses an urgent danger to the protocol and as such support this weeks executive.

Polls ending 15th of December 2022 Change of Ownership of the Ambassador’s Program Multi-Sig Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is a voluntary change based on Kat stepping down. I don’t see any conflicts of interests that could arise from the change of owner and thus support this change. Dai Foundation Board Member Election Poll Voted: Neither Candidate Reasoning: First off, I would like to clarify that I think both candidates can do a good job for Maker so the voting is a little misleading. I voted that way because the vote didn’t require an urgent resolution and at the time there were a few open questions. I’m happy those have been answered and I’m happy the community has made their choice. Best of luck to @Daimon-Law in his new role. Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit (SAS-001) Funding Request Voted: Yes Reasoning: I voted against the past budget proposal for SAS-001. The main reason is because I believe it is important that we start the transition into the end-game organizational set-up. This request ask for a possibility to do that. It thus seems reasonable to me to grant this request in a transitional period to minimize friction. Governance Communications Core Unit (COM-001) Funding Request Voted: Yes Reasoning: Same logic and reasoning as in the SAS proposal above. Ratification Poll for Pioneer DeFi-focused Language Dataset for the Benefit of Risk Modelling & Governance Communication (MIP55c3-SP11) Voted: No Reasoning: While this proposal presents a very interesting take and is very much in line with automating processes it does run into some difficulties of acceptance. The way Maker is structured there is a certain incumbent advantage when it comes to evaluate the merits of new ideas. This particular incumbent advantage will be lessened with the implementation of the endgame plan. In our current organizational setup I’m inclined to follow the recommendations of the existing Risk CU. I would much rather this particular proposal be worked on in collaboration with them. Often, even great ideas, benefits from constructive debate. There is also something to be said for a proven track record. While existing risk models may not be perfect they have served us well in what can be described as a very volatile market, far in excess of what we have seen in more traditional markets. Over time I’m certain we can tune our models to have more accurate parameters but until that time I think it pays to adopt a conservative stance and maintain stricter parameters than we might need.

Executive 11th of January 2023 Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this weeks executive as usual given that nothing malicious was detected during due diligence. Polls ending 12th of January 2023 Approve One-time MKR Distribution to Correct CES-001 Incentive Program Shortfall Voted: Yes Reasoning: Deciding on this took a fair while. Maker governance has approved a certain stream of MKR to cover for the incentive program for CES-001. As such it is my base view that any shortfall falls on CES-001 to cover. However this picture is complicated by the fact that those benefiting from the shortfall is no longer part of the CU and those being hurt by the shortfall is. I am also satisfied that avenues have been explored with regards to reclaiming the missing MKR. As an overall evaluation I’m therefore reluctantly supporting this request. This requests shows very clearly that the current budgeting oversight is lacking. In particular when it comes to off boarding scenarios. This is not the first time funds have ended up with the wrong recipients. I believe the endgame will provide some solution to this but there will also be other more short term solutions that needs to be implemented to avoid similar issues going forward. Confirm Trial Deployment of DssKiln Voted: 1. 3 Million 2. 2 Million 3. 1 Million 4. 0,5 Million Reasoning: The burn has been a distant dream since early last year when a emergency executive raised the surplus buffer to 250 million with no reasoning behind it other than preventing further burn. Prior to that the size of the surplus buffer was a compromise between the need for a mechanism to let MKR holders take part in the protocols success and risk and capital buffer on the other hand. So a single vote to shut of the burn has lead to a whole series of votes to attempt to turn it back on. Several of these successful, yet not implemented. Thus having yet another one seems very superfluous, yet here we are. The arguments in favor of the burn has not disappeared and if anything the current low valuation of the token makes this a fantastic time to initiate such a burn. Sadly it seems this particular vote fails so I guess there will have to be another one followed by a confirmation one, followed by yet another confirming one 6 months after the first two has passed before we maybe implement it. This polls also shows the necessity of governance reform where passed governance proposals are actually implemented. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: Disclaimer of conflict of interest. I have personal vaults of StETH (Low fee). To address the conflict of interest first. I am happy to see the stability fee of this particular vault rise. Even so I believe the current levels are too low. It should as a minimum be ETH Low fee + a risk premium. As we have seen reducing the fee of this particular vault has mostly just shifted collateral out of other StEth. Time to fully end the sponsoring of this vault. I’m very happy to see the tin of USDP increase a further 0.1% point. USDP has yet to engage with Maker in a revenue share program. With the increase in our DSR to 1% this particular PSM represents a net negative yield as well as constituting a counterparty risk. Unless some of these parameters changes I believe it is in Maker’s interest to disincentivize its use. Overall I’m happy with the changes and support the proposal.

Polls ending 19th of January 2023 Adjust the GUSD PSM Debt Ceiling Voted: No change (500 Million DAI) Reasoning: While I’m not thrilled with the considerable portion of GUSD of overall market cap in Maker’s possession I do not believe a reduction in debt ceiling is a very productive proposal. Reducing this would not have any immediate effect except signal distrust. Maintaining obligations is a core value of my delegate platform and thus it is my belief that we can accomplish more by engaging in dialogue than simply changing a parameter. The current arrangement we have regarding GUSD is at a juncture where we need to re-evaluate, both  the rewards in relation to exposure, but also the transparency when it comes to the placement by the counter-party. It’s my clear belief that steps are being taken in this direction and depending on where they lead we might have to re-visit this or a similar proposal. Decrease GUSD PSM Fee Out (tout) Voted: No Reasoning: This proposal should be viewed in conjunction with the previous one. I believe encouraging a reduction in GUSD exposure is premature until other options to improve the risk/reward equation has been attempted. Even so given the sizable exposure from a single actor, this move by itself is unlikely to provide a meaningful change. With the competency Maker has built through other RWA exposure we have mechanisms to deploy GUSD on our own to both increase revenue and decrease exposure if other arrangements cannot be reached.

Polls ending 23rd of January 2023 Ratification Poll for MIP63 Maker Keeper Network Amendment (MIP4c2-SP31) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal amends MIP-63 that governs the Maker Keeper Network. It clarifies a few issues that was previously only implied. A needed housekeeping task containing minor changes. Ratification Poll for Defense Fund (MIP55c3-SP14) Voted: Yes Reasoning: While I’m neither thrilled by the the existance of such a fund nor the reason it is suggested, I do think it pays to be prepared. The way this fund is structured it is my belief that overall it does more good than harm. It also makes sense to deal with potential legal action from a collective standpoint as nobody knows who might be the one on the receiving end. Ratification Poll for Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn to earn Yield (MIP92) Voted: No Reasoning: While I’m generally in favor of proposals seeking to generate revenue from our PSMs I think the overall risk/reward on this particular proposal means Maker should decline. The big weakness with this particular proposal is firstly that the strategies are possible to do directly by Maker. Secondly the fee is initially high, but more importantly is based on a performance. A performance based fee stacks incentives towards risk taking behavior. As the provider of capital, Maker will thus be exposed for the full risk with only a portion of the rewards. The provider is incentivised to maximize the fee through increased risk. Given that there is a finite amount of USDC to deploy I think Maker is better served by using other solutions. Ratification Poll for Declaration of Intent to Develop a Comprehensive On-chain Monitoring Solution for RWA Vaults (MIP13c3-SP13) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This is an easy proposal to support. With the growing number of RWA collateral and the unfortunate dissolution of the RWF core unit, it’s high time Maker paid closer attention. A proposal like this gets the ball rolling until more permanent solutions can be put into place. Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network Voted: Yes Reasoning: Lately Chainlink has provided a meaningful portion of the work of the Keeper Network. Onboarding them seems like the sensible thing to do as it strengthens the network overall. Ratification Poll for Special Purpose Fund for developing Proof-of-Performance for Viridian Cluster (MIP55c3-SP13) Voted: No Reasoning: There is a conflict of interest present in this proposal. In order to ensure proper monitoring of assets, that control should come from outside the entity being controlled. While this proposal would presumably increase monitoring and safety somewhat Maker should base their control efforts outside the entity being controlled. Ratification Poll for Requesting Protocol DAI Transfer to fund TechOps CU for February 2023 (MIP14c2-SP1) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Tech Ops was one first core units to start the transition to ecosystem actor. As such Maker has a vested interest in seeing them succeed and chart a course for others to follow. In order to do so successfully they require resources, especially in light of the end-game plan and constitution getting pushed back by 6 months. Ratification Poll for Core Unit Offboarding (COM-001) (MIP39c3-SP7) Voted:  Approve Offboarding, 60,700 DAI Golden Parachute and 80% Multiplier for retroactive MKR - additional 85,854 DAI Reject Options  Reasoning: As another core unit transitioning early to ecosystem actor it seems sensible to ensure funding to wind down. On principle I am against retroactive compensations as it goes against my core value of maintaining obligations. As such I was very much in doubt whether to approve any of the options granting such compensation. Still in recognition of the work put in by the core unit and not least to ease the transition an exception seems appropriate in this case. Ratification Poll for Remove MIP14c4 (Protocol DAI Transfer Ceiling) (MIP4c2-SP32) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Due to the transition to the end-game there is likely to be an increase in the usage of MIP-14. In order to expedite governance and reduce governance overhead it seems reasonable to remove the cap associated with MIP-14. Ratification Poll for Obsolete MIP Removal (MIP23, MIP28) (MIP4c4-SP3) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal removes MIPs for a framwork that is no longer being used. Getting rid of redundant MIPs makes the remaining ones more accessible. Ratification Poll for MIP14 Repeal (MIP4c4-SP2) Voted: No Reasoning: With the transition to the endgame there is a high likelyhood we will not only need MIP14 but that the need for it will even surpass the use we have seen in the past. As such it seems ill advised to remove it entirely. As the end-game is more implemented we can re-visit this proposal. Ratification Poll for Amend MIP51 to Remove MIP51c4 (Calendar Exceptions) (MIP4c2-SP28) Voted: No Resoning: While I can appreciate the intention behind this proposal, it is my clear view that anything that is time critical can be passed withing the calendar exceptions. Glancing to the calendar and having certain periods of low activity helps structure the overall flow of work and assists in maintaining contributors who might otherwise risk burning out. Ratification Poll for Amend MIP61 to tighten up Recognized Delegate Participation Metrics (MIP4c2-SP29) Voted: Yes to both Reasoning: Not all parts of governance is equally important and making sure governance flows is a prime consideration. Following that logic it makes sense that participation of executives should be more heavily weighted than other polls. Voting abstain has its place in governance and should be available and counted as participation, but there comes a point where it ceases to be a useful tool and becomes open to abuse. The proposal as written removes the most obvious edge case. Governance should require participation even if one disagrees with the current strategic direction.

Polls ending 26th of January 2023. Offboarding Parameters for USDC-A, USDP-A, and GUSD-A Voted: Yes Reasoning: Given that Maker wants stablecoins to be in PSMs it is high time we got rid of the older vaults. The proposed parameters seems to achieve the desired results. Adjust the Debt Floor (dust) Voted: 1. Option 1 - Broad Reduction 2. Option 2 - Limited Reduction Resoning: Dust limits are in essence a trade-off between accessibility and risk. The determining factor is gas cost, both on average and in cases of stress. Maker needs to ensure there is not bad debt being accrued on account of too high gas costs in a liquidation event. In opposition is the need to keep vaults accessible. There is no point in having vaults that are guaranteed to never accrue bad debts if the dust limits are so high nobody can gather enough collateral to use them. In general Maker’s vaults are not optimized for smaller users. However, Maker seeks to be as permissionless as possible. The idea of being permisionless seems to align to making vaults as accessible as reasonably possible. Following this logic the right course of action would be to seek as low dust limit as possible. Executive 27th of January 2023 MOMC Parameter Changes, GUSD PSM tout Decrease, CES MKR Transfer, Flash Mint Module Upgrade, Cage Aave D3M Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported the current executive in line with my regular stance on governance.

Poll ending 2nd of February 2022 Short Ratification Poll for Requesting Protocol DAI Transfer to Fund Endgame Information Portal (MIP14c2-SP3) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Going back and forth on this proposal I ended up on a marginal yes. The endgame is a monumental undertaking and with many and complex interactions. Having information more accessible seems to be a growing necessity from several stakeholders. As such this proposal represents a step forward. It’s not a final solution and might not even be an optimal solution, but it is progress. It also has the advantage of being a low cost proposal. On the other hand there is an inherent weakness that this is merely the infrastructure to gather information and not the information itself. It also stands separate from other sources of information which is not ideal. Executive 3rd of February 2022 Maker Teleport Temporary Shutdown, DAI Transfers, Starknet Contract Deauthorizations Voted: Yes Reasoning: A sizable executive yet nothing that presents a danger to the protocol. Supported in order to maintain efficient governance.

Executive 8th of February 2023 Dust Parameter Changes, Chainlink Automation Keeper Network Stream Setup, Recognized Delegate Compensation for January Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported the current executive to enact approved changes. Nothing found to be immediately harmful to the protocol. Polls ending 9th of February 2023 Update the Multisig Managing the Velodrome NFT Voted: Yes Reasoning: A housekeeping task to update the multisig with new signers that are more active contributors. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: Declaration of conflict of interest: This delegate currently utilizes a WSTETH-B vault and is thus affected of the proposed changes. The overall direction of this proposal is more or less steady. It does contain some changes that would hopefully cause big improvements for certain collateral. In the last MOMC proposal I applauded the rising of the WSTETH-B vault from 0% to 0.25%. Seeing this trend continue with a further increase to 0.5% seems very prudent. Now the SF matches that of ETH-C which is a good start. It also needs to account for the added risk of being staked ETH on top of that so aiming to match ETH-A seems like a decent goal, even if it might be a little on the hawkish side. The decrease in SF on rETH is intentionally subsidizing this particular vault in relation to risk parameters. With the current debt ceiling this should be manageable but I would like to see a return to proper risk parameters sooner rather than later. In a more general sense the reduction of stability fees to entice increased usage has been of limited success in the past, but given the relatively low impact it has on overall revenue, it may be worth doing this experiment again.

Poll ending 16th of February 2023 Ratification Poll for Restart a daily $100 Micro-Burn of MKR in Show of Good Faith to MKR Holders (MIP74c1-SP1) Voted: Yes Reasoning: As I’m writing this it’s been over a year since the last time the protocol bought back and burned DAI. Trying to re-ignite this particular mechanism has been a goal for this delegate ever since. Given the rapidly changing market conditions and Maker starting to deplete the surplus buffer this naturally meant shifting the focus towards increasing revenue and decreasing costs. After all Maker cannot burn more than it accumulates. Seeing the unwillingness to even extend a nod to this mechanism with a completely insignificant economic is a blow for those of us wishing for an autonomous depreciation of the MKR token. Given the massive reduction in exposure on risky debt the surplus buffer is at time of writing considerably larger than necessary, let alone require a limit of $250M.

Executive 22nd of February 2023. Aave v2 D3M Deployment, Strategic Finance MKR Vesting Streams, and MOMC Parameter Changes Voted: Yes Reasoning: Supported this week’s executive enacting previously succesfully polled changes. Gradually improving the protocol and ensuring effective governance. Polls ending 23rd of February 2023. Audit and Review Work for Phoenix Labs Voted: Yes Reasoning: It is good to see the question of PE resource allocation put up for a poll. This is a logical extention of the direction Maker governance has decided in approving the endgame plan. Even so seeking the explicit confirmation seems like the right thing to do. The creation of SubDAOs is integral to the success of the endgame and thus is a neccessary step that should be taken. Naturally this also comes with an opportunity cost, but in my view that is acceptable in the current circumstances. Engineering Resource for Phoenix Labs Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal is closely tied to the other and deals with the same issue. As such the reasoning stands even if this is for a different resource.

Polls ending 27th of February 2023. Ratification Poll - Declaration of Intent - Implement a Feature to Refund People who Lost Money Sending Dai to the Dai Contract Address Voted: No Reasoning: The major reason for voting no to this proposal is opportunity cost. While it is unfortunate that users through error lose their DAI but this proposal has illustrated that the sums involved makes it hard to justify the development costs. Longer term I think it would be prudent to look into such a mechanism, but more importantly I think improvements in UI will reduce the numbers and scale of incidents going forward. Ratification Poll for Amend MIP62 to Allow for Changing Communication Responsibilities (MIP4c2-SP33) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal ties up a loose end after GovComs core unit transitioned to become an ecosystem actor. Transfering the responsibility to GovAlpha seems a sensible alternative. Ratification Poll for Amend Interim Facilitator Appointment Process (MIP4c2-SP30) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal ammends the interim facilitator process. After having some sub-optimal experiences with interim facilitators this proposal tightens up the process and brings more clarity. Most processes becomes refined through usage so this seems like a good evolutionary step. Ratification Poll for $100M of Cogent Bank Loan Participations (MIP95) Voted: Yes Reasoning: This proposal bear many resemblances to HVB bank. It allows for Maker to expand to a new geographic area and establish a comercial relationship with another real world actor. This proposal does require more due dilligence than going into government bonds. With the proposed changes coming into effect this kind of proposal will have to pass out of Maker core and be adopted by a subDAO but it should be similar enough to HVB that the process shouldn’t add too much extra work. Despite the difficulties incurred with the changes coming with the end-game I think it would be worth investigating to get a jump start on the process and make it ready for transition to subDAO.

Poll ending 2nd of March 2023 PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal Voted: Yes Reasoning: With the increase of the DAI savings rate (DSR) to 1% it’s nice to see a proposal to increase stability fees to match this new reality. Any stability fee below the DSR is long term unsustainable and needs to be adressed. Any fee should be in excess of the DSR in order to account to the risk incurred to the protocol. The proposed changes represents a measured and controlled increase and it is this delegate’s belief that we will see continued movement in this direction over the coming months.

Executive 8th of March 2022 CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Liquidation Parameter Changes, Stablecoin Vault Offboarding, MOMC Parameter Changes, Budget Distributions, Recognized Delegate Compensation for February Voted: Yes Reasoning: The regularly scheduled executive. Supported to effectuate already polled governance. Nothing deemed critical to the protocol that warrants withholding support. Polls ending 9th of March 2022 Short Ratification Poll for Phoenix Labs Initial Funding (MIP55c3-SP15) Voted: Yes Reasoning: Given Maker’s stated intention to implement the endgame it logically follows that structures needs to be prepared to get ready for the change. This proposal authorizes funds to incorporate and launch Phoenix labs as one of the inititial organizational structures aiming to transition to a creator sub-DAO. Change takes time and this ask seems appropriate to get preparations underway. Decrease the RETH-A Dust Parameter Voted: Yes Reasoning: Adjusting dust parameters in order to account for changing market conditions is important to ensure we neither expose the protocol to excessive risk balanced against user accessibility. In this particular case there is room to reduce the dust limit without taking excessive risk in order to give users with lower total funds the opportunity to open vaults. Dust limits are necessary but should’t be excessive so I support this change. Emergency executive 11th of March 2022 Emergency Parameter Changes Voted: Yes Reasoning: This executive is in direct response to market conditions resulting from the uncertain future of SVB and the ripple effects this has caused. Most notably and critical to Maker is the depegging of USDC and the following depegging of DAI due to the sizable exposure to USDC through the PSM. The changes contained in this executive seeks to limit the most immediate exposures of the protocol as well as limit the influx of USDC in the PSM while a further assessment can be made. It is the view of this delegate that these measures will be highly temporary and I’ll be surprised if they remain in excess of a week. This situation illustrates the need for Maker to further diversify our PSM portfolio and exposure to other collateral. Work on that diversification has already started but should be intensified as a consequence of the turbulence we are currently experiencing. Maker should further its role as a responsible actor in DeFi that will support the ecosystem and ensure stability of stablecoins.

Emergency Executive 14th of March 2023 Emergency PSM Changes Voted: Yes Reasoning: Voted in favor of the second emergency executive within the span of a week. This one contains emergency changes to the PSM allowing Maker to bypass the pause proxy to set the three PEG stability modules to 0 immediately. It’s intended to provide protection in the event of further market turbulence where other stablecoins depegs significantly to allow DAI to more easily maintain the peg. This change provides an immediate emergency response but also underscores the importance of finding more permanent long term solutions to peg stability. Polls ending March 16th 2023 Remove the DC-IAM from MIP65 (RWA007-A) Voted: No Reasoning: This proposal removes the DC-IAM and will allow access to the full increase of any debt ceiling increase to MIP-65 immediately instead of increasing it by 100M every week until it reaches maximum. This allows quicker access to the full revenue but carries a larger risk. There exists some uncertainty in the relationship between the foundation and the arranger in the MIP-65 structure that I think would be prudent to remove before removing this particular safeguard. My expectation is that it would be cleared and we could reintroduce this proposal in a week or two with minimal disruption to operations. It also seems preferable to delaying any and all increase to the DC of MIP-65. Increase the MIP65 (RWA007-A) Debt Ceiling Voted: Yes Reasoning: If it wasn’t clear before the events of last weekend showed the importance of having clarity in where the assets backing the peg are and how available and safe they are. Being as connected to other stable coins assessments and exposure is a major risk that needs to be addressed. MIP-65 offers the one structure available that can rapidly deploy large sums of capital into safe assets and that can also increase the protocols revenue. Given that other providers have been slow in offering Maker revenue share proportional to the risk it exposes the protocol to it seems prudent to deploy the capital in order to reduce counter party risk and increase revenue to be able to absorb any potential losses that may occur. Short Ratification Poll for Vault Setting Amendment Subproposal (MIP92c5-SP1) Voted: No Reasoning: Given the recent turmoil surrounding USDC culminating in the depeg that also affected DAI adversely it seems prudent to do re-evaluate Maker’s total exposure to USDC going forward. Until such a time, I think this proposal should be delayed. Return Excess MIP65 Funds to Surplus Buffer Voted: Yes Reasoning: Highly excited to support this proposal. It’s imperative that Maker evaluates its risks across all operations and the one place that ties everything together is the surplus buffer. As such any and all excess liquidity should be returned there to be fully evaluated before being deployed into anything else. As such this proposal should not only pass now, but for the basis for a standard operational procedure where every month any excess from MIP-65 (and any similar structures that might be made) is returned to the Surplus Buffer.

Constitution MIP Set Ratification Poll for the Constitution MIP Set Voted: No Reasoning: Executive summary: In my view this highly complex and comprehensive proposal delivers more negative effects than it does positive. The primary flaws are listed below:  The opportunity cost of this reform is already considerable, having consumed most of the DAO’s resources for the past 6 months, potentially leaving existential risks to the protocol unaddressed. With the passage of the proposal the old governance system is abolished while the constitution is still neither finished nor tested. The creation of sub- or meta- DAOs does not sufficiently protect Maker core from substantial potential losses. Governance increases in complexity. The introduction of token emission coupled with a changed and limited burn mechanic is a probable cause of token devaluation. Unless the token is locked long term into contracts it is diluted. Poor minority token protection and diminished token utility.  In sum, the potential gains are uncertain and will further require so much of protocol resources that it risks the future of the protocol. It presents a clear devaluation of the token for any MKR holder not willing to fully commit to a long-term commitment to Maker governance. Further reasoning: I started my journey as a delegate because I was a MKR holder with a significant portion of my personal net value in MKR because I believed in the protocol and because I thought it had the potential to transform finance. During my tenure I have always voted what I believed to be in the interest of MKR holders both large and small. It didn’t matter to me whether I voted with a small or a large amount of delegated MKR, my motivation and assessments remained the same. What have guided me however has been the three core values described in my delegate platform:  Maintaining obligations Growing the profitability of the protocol Simplicity  The constitution as it is presented now presents to me a breach to every one of those core values. I’m aware that it is a work in progress and that it is subject to change, but that has seemingly also been the case as long as I have attended the CVC/DVC calls. The constitution as it is now presented, is a very different beast than the end-game plan as it was presented as a concept in the first meeting back on the 17th of May 2022. The fact that it is so clearly labelled as a work in progress also makes me deeply uncomfortable with bundling this with a dismantling of existing governance. It is clear to me that substantial work is required before this proposal is ready to fully support governance. It is equally clear to me that it represents a major increase in complexity of governance. This complexity is passed on to MKR token holders that is now required to participate or risk seeing their holdings diluted. One possibility is that MKR token holders are willing to pay that investment in time and energy, another possibility is deciding that this token is no longer right for them and dispensing it for other tokens. In my opinion this proposal puts too much faith into the first option while the current trend in the market seems to indicate many choosing the second option. There is a saying that code is law. In this context I’d like to turn it on its head and point out that laws are functionally social code. I can’t see Maker signing off on a piece of code that isn’t fully written and then tested before implementation, yet that is exactly what this proposal is asking for. It is also asking to delete the current operating system while working on the new one. To me this is reckless and irresponsible. I’ll use snippet below to illustrate just how much of a work in progress the current proposal is:  image863×350 45.1 KB  Regarding MetaDAO and SubDAO, it is still very much unclear how Maker core is protected in the eventuality of any one of them failing. This is of particular concern, given that they are meant to take on risk deemed too high by the core. The proposal as presented thus presents a clear increase in risk tolerance for the protocol. A big risk this proposal introduces to the protocol is opportunity cost. For those who frequent the forums the reduction in meaningful discussions on new creative proposals and solutions to the protocol outside of the constitution has been noticeable. Maker’s exposure to stablecoins, and in particular USDC has been hotly debated before and the consensus is that something needs to be done. The solutions have varied and remain disputed, but the recent de-peg has shown in force how existential this threat is, and how dire the need to address it is. Unfortunately, most of Maker’s resources are now focused on the implementation and consequences of the constitution. While there is potential that scopes will be able to address this issue, it still seems like a lot more work is needed before this will be a fully usable solution. Another potential negative effect of this proposal is the introduction of uncertainty for contributors. The structure and final form is in constant flux leaving contributors in a state of limbo until a final form is agreed upon. This presents a risk in contributors leaving as well as in wasting effort in pursuing plans and options that are subsequently dropped further down the line. While many things done at Maker presents cutting edge technological solutions and needs to go to unchartered waters, this is not true for every aspect of what Maker does. There exists a substantial body of work on organizational theory and how to incentivize contributors. This plan seeks a novel approach and is not founded on any prior research, at least none that has been referenced. The burn mechanic in its current form has also been a hotly debated topic and its resumption was one the elements in the original end-game plan. While it still exists, it is now countered by various planned token emissions which are functionally reverse burning. This coupled with other dilution mechanics, most notably from not being locked in governance, reduces the utility of the token for anyone not fully invested in becoming part of Maker governance. Barring some sudden influx of interested parties, this is likely to put considerable sell pressure and devaluation on the token. Given the reasoning stated above I cannot in good conscience vote in favour of this proposal, at least not in its current form at this time.

ACREinvest Key Info Delegate Address: 0x4d3aC33AB1dd7B0F352b8E590Fe8b62c4C39eAd5 Forum: @ACREimpact External Website: https://www.acreinvest.xyz Meet Your Delegate Video: Expected December 8 Core Values  Creativity Common Sense Compliance  Delegate Statement I’m the Founder of Acre of America, an impact investment management & advisory firm working at the intersection of new technologies & rural problems from headquarters in Hudson, New York, USA. ACREinvest is our new blockchain venture focused on creating compelling Web3 infrastructure, virtual network services and social incentives for DAOs and other peer-to-peer permissionless stakeholders. We recently launched ACRE DAOs, a Web3 portal for a decentralized impact investment club and its related community ERC-20 token: ACRE Impact. Our Mission at ACREinvest is to regenerate the way capital markets work & for whom. I’m excited to apply two decades of prior legal experience in derivatives and commodities markets to the world of DeFi, and MakerDAO specifically. New products and regulatory policy in markets have long been a hallmark of my work and professional fascination. I’ve been down the crypto rabbit hole full-time since 2017 and have been an avid follower-fan of MakerDAO since that time. Until now I have not had the capacity to dig-in actively on governance, so I’m thrilled to have a wonderful team in place at Acre of America to provide me with this opportunity to nerd out with you all. Further, I am keen to inform the wider world about this important work and experimental process by  publishing online content for a general finance savvy audience that is DeFi and crypto curious. I began my legal career as a Corporate Associate in the derivatives practice group at Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP in New York City after graduating from Spelman College and the Yale Law School. Clients included the International Swaps and Derivatives Association (“ISDA”) and as ISDA’s U.S. Outside Counsel I coordinated the work of several sell-side working groups that published documentation and resolved legal, commercial, regulatory and operational issues facing derivatives markets, including for the then-emerging credit derivatives market and launch of the Euro. In later roles I gained extensive deal and transactional experience supporting the fixed-income derivatives, currencies/FX, derivatives prime brokerage and energy trading businesses at Goldman Sachs; derivatives and physical commodities trading at Lehman Brothers; and global commodities merchant trading businesses at Castleton Commodities International. Conflicts of Interest Acre of America does not have any significant conflicts of interest at this time. I pledge to keep the community updated on any developments with our products and services that could present a conflict of interest, and will also inform of personal conflicts that would be appropriate to disclose as a result of any legal client representation or tradfi-style client advisory/asset management obligations. I have read and agree to abide by the Delegate Code of Conduct.  LEGAL DISCLAIMER Kianga Daverington’s role as a delegate is NOT in her professional capacity as attorney. None of Kianga’s comments or communications is legal advice and should not be relied upon as such. Kianga’s contributions to this community are in a commercial capacity on behalf of ACREinvest, notwithstanding that her perspective is strongly influenced by legal knowledge. You are not a legal client of Kianga Daverington or her law office, Daverington PLLC, by delegating MKR to ACREinvest. ACREinvest offers to vote and contribute to the MakerDAO governance process with the best interest of the overall community mission in-mind, as determined in its sole discretion. ACREinvest does not have a fiduciary obligation to you as a result of your delegation of MKR to our delegation contract. WAIVER OF LIABILITY By delegating to ACREinvest you acknowledge and agree that neither Kianga Daverington nor ACREinvest, its owners, agents and affiliates, are liable for any form of damages or losses related to your delegation of your MKR to ACREinvest. By delegating your MKR you accept the outcome of votes made on your behalf by ACREinvest due to your ownership of MKR. It is your responsibility to understand the risks and costs related to delegation of your MKR, and specifically affirm and agree that at all times you have complete control over the delegated assets by adding or removing your MKR from our delegation contract.

content.content: General Update & January Signal Request Votes January 2022 marks the completion of our first full month as an active Recognized Delegate! ACREinvest received its first delegation of 1,000 MKR on December 14, 2021. During the past six weeks I have been actively listening, learning, reading posts and discussions here in the Forum, attending community meetings and following conversations in our Discord server and Twitter.  And, of course, doing some voting. We have also been hard at work to recruit talented individuals for active participation in Maker Governance through membership at ACRE DAOs, the Web3 impact investment club our firm sponsors. Membership in ACRE DAOs means a person or anon holds 1,000 $ACRE tokens pursuant to an Open Call for Founding Members during the month of December 2021, or via a later distribution of tokens as a reward for participation or other valuable contribution to the ACRE (Autonomous Communities for Regenerative Economies) community. I believe that scaling successful DAO governance requires a social component where individuals who know each other have fun sharing insights and knowledge among a small group. Accordingly, ACREinvest has established a New Products Working Group (NPWG) within ACRE DAOs to experiment with a targeted team approach to increasing permissionless participation and engagement. As of today there are two ACRE DAOs members engaged as thought partners and collaborators through the ACRE DAOs - MKRDAO - NPWG. Participants must be verified ACRE Impact token holders in the ACRE DAOs Discord Server. They will assist me in monitoring the day-to-day happenings at Maker DAO and with subject matter expert analysis, and may also engage directly via their own Forum accounts and independently on Social channels such as Twitter and Discord. To incentivize quality engagement for the long term, we are offering members of this working group a share of our overall Delegate Compensation and $ACRE token rewards commensurate with the value of their contribution to Maker in general, and our analysis for voting purposes as a Recognized Delegate in particular. I, Kianga Daverington, continue to be the sole decider for voting by ACREinvest. In the weeks ahead, ACREinvest will be more active in communicating views on the relevant forum posts ahead of votes. We will use updates to this Delegate Platform to provide monthly summaries of how we voted and why (with links to where we have shared views in other parts of the Forum). Thank you to all members of the community, proposers and Core Units who have reached out privately and assisted me with education, history, context and technical support! Yours truly, Kianga Daverington Founder, ACREinvest  [Signal Request] Extend the Delegate Compensation Trial  Voted YES -  Providing compensation to Recognized Delegates is an important signal to the market and our various stakeholders that the community values a high level of professionalism, commitment and quality within our decentralized governance function.

content.content: February Signal Request Votes  [Signal Request] SourceCred, stop paying people who are already paid by MakerDAO  Signal was withdrawn before I could vote, but my leaning was to vote NO per this comment [Signal Request] SourceCred, stop paying people who are already paid by MakerDAO - #29 by ACREinvest  SourceCred should be available to everyone, anyone and maintained/rewarded strictly as the algorithm works to reward engagement on the Forum. Every participant and potential participant should be so incentivized to be as knowledgeable as possible about as many discussions/topics as possible. Even if a person spent every waking hour devoted to MakerDAO, there’s more going on here than any human can keep up with while also bringing valuable, informed contributions to the table. Having SourceCred rewards signals that we value the effort everyone is making and hopefully the extra DAI correlated with that effort, makes it more fun and satisfying to engage in the activity. The amount of payment itself surely isn’t the sole or even in my case a significant factor. The program expresses appreciation which is otherwise hard to feel from a decentralized group. It says, hey - we see you and your efforts here. Thank you! There’s a psychological component here I haven’t seen mentioned.   [Signal Request] Advance “Rapid Payment for Small Bug Bounties” to on-chain poll  Voted YES - Pro-security and efficient DAO operations FTW!  [Signal Request] Raise Gemini Dollar (GUSD) PSM Debt Ceiling To 60 Million DAI  Voted YES - My comment on the corresponding on-chain polling vote:  Notwithstanding the recent drop in utilization, raising the debt ceiling at this time signals our interest and support for diversifying the PSM, and distributing counterparty risk with high-quality issuers such as Gemini.   [Signal Request] MakerMan Retroactive Delegate Comp  Voted ABSTAIN - My comment on the corresponding on-chain polling vote:  Because the activity related to this poll pre-dates my tenure as a Delegate, I vote to Abstain. However, I hold the principles of immutability and predictability in the highest regard. Retroactive “fixes” can infect governance with moral hazard.   [Signal Request] Implement Governance Mining Trial  Voted NO -    [Signal Request] Implement Governance Mining Trial Signal Requests       I voted no for reasons well stated by @wouter @LongForWisdom and co-signed emphatically by @oxdeniz with further comments by @Andrew_Hall about improving delegation here: [Signal Request] Implement Governance Mining Trial - #30 by Andrew_Hall Honorable mention @williamscofflaw [Signal Request] Implement Governance Mining Trial - #11 by williamscofflaw. @Doo_Nam also makes an important point that appreciates how much time and dedication it takes to become even modestly informed enough to vote on …

Voted NO with the following on-chain comments:  I am voting no because we have enough exposure to Treasuries and US Federal Reserve risk via USDC. The proposal moves us away from the anti-fragile decentralized stablecoin structure I’d like to see in the world.  Community Greenlight Poll - STABLE-TBILL (US Treasury Securities Up To 12 Months Duration) - January 24, 2022 Signal your support or opposition to prioritising onboarding STABLE-TBILL (US Treasury Securities Up To 12 Months Duration). Voted YES in line with my previous support of delegate compensation as a necessary element for incentivizing the high level of professional, sustainable, consistent and quality governance MakerDAO requires. Offloading TUSD-A - February 7, 2022 Rank your preferred options to resolve the proposed offloading of TUSD collateral. Voted YES for reasons discussed here:    [Signal Request] Offloading TUSD-A Signal Requests       In my view of the world, unfinished business sitting dormant for a year has a way of putting a psychic drain on everything else. I am absolutely in favor of cleaning this up and running a tight ship. Agreeing here with @hexonaut on taking the path of least resistance and not putting pressure on devs. I voted to activate liquidations.     Introduce Rate Limiting into the Flapper - February 7, 2022 Signal your support or opposition to restarting the MKR burn by introducing Rate Limiting into the Flapper. Voted NO as I misread this poll as being a proposal to bring back the MKR burn per the related Signal Request. I do support the decision to introduce rate limiting into the Flapper. 1 Poll - Ended Feb 17 2022 16:00 UTC Increase the PSM-GUSD Debt Ceiling - February 14, 2022 Signal your support or opposition for adjusting the PSM-GUSD Debt Ceiling from 10 million DAI to 60 million DAI. Voted YES and posted this comment on-chain:  Notwithstanding the recent drop in utilization, raising the debt ceiling at this time signals our interest and support for diversifying the PSM, and distributing counterparty risk with high-quality issuers such as Gemini.  With additional comments here:    [EXECUTIVE VOTE NOTICE] 3F Delegate Cannot Support an INCREASE of the GUSD PSM Debt Ceiling Governance       May I ask what is the harm and/or significant opportunity cost to increasing the GUSD PSM debt ceiling? Diversifying issuer risk among high quality stablecoins in the PSM should be a top priority. Gemini fits the bill! The immediate situation of low utilization does not concern me other than to demonstrate that we need a strategic effort to strengthen the relationship. This increase will serve as a signal to the market of our priorities and focus in this regard.     1 Poll - Ended Feb 24 2022 16:00 UTC MakerMan Retroactive Delegate Compensation - February 21, 2022 Signal your support or opposition to compensating MakerMan for Recognized Delegate activities in the month of November. I voted ABSTAIN with the following on-chain comments:  Because the activity related to this poll pre-dates my tenure as a Delegate, I vote to Abstain. However, I hold the principles of immutability and predictability in the highest regard. Retroactive “fixes” can infect governance with moral hazard.  8 Polls - Ended Feb 28 2022 16:00 UTC Ratification Poll for Facilitator Onboarding to DUX-001 - 0xdeniz (MIP41c4-SP32) - February 14, 2022 This subproposal is to onboard @0xdeniz as Facilitator to the Development and UX Core Unit (DUX-001). Ratification Poll for Intangible Asset Assignment (MIP60) - February 14, 2022 MIP60 sets processes for MakerDAO to determine which actors manage which Intangible Assets (such as web domains, GitHub repositories, and social media accounts). Voted YES - Uncontroversial orderly business continuance proposal. 1 Poll - Ending Mar 07 2022 16:00 UTC Community Greenlight Poll - PUNK (NTFX CryptoPunk) - February 21, 2022 Voted No per comments here:     [PUNK] Collateral Onboarding Application Collateral Onboarding Applications (MIP6)       Thank you for this thoughtful reply @MakerMan. I agree with your views and also do not support this MIP.  Let me add that even with ample resources I would recommend we focus on the long-term vision and those highly strategic capacities and counterparties that will get us there. content.content: March Signal Request Votes  [Signal Request] Promote “MIP4c3-SP1: Amend MIP64 to clarify critical web bounty amount” to on-chain poll  Voted YES - good adjustment to refine and strengthen the Bug Bounty program.  [Signal Request] Fund Ambassadors Program Pilot  Voted YES - this is crucial work and must be resourced to do well. I’m eager to see communications and operations optimized for global participation and perspectives.  [Signal Request] Promote “MIP4c3-SP2: MIP62 Amendments” to an on-chain poll  Voted YES - it is good governance to have clarifications and administrative fixes go through a process of verification.  [Signal Request] Onboard PAXG  Voted NO - not a fan of gold-backed cryptocurrency [Signal Request] Onboard PAXG - #24 by ACREinvest  As a personal aside, I find the idea that gold is great for DeFi to be hilariously ironic and false. I’m assuming a tokenized gold product functions or trades like a cash-settled futures contract (?), but do admit I am not yet familiar with this particular instrument. In any case, all that we are trying to innovate away from in DeFi is brought right back to center with onboarding a precious metal/commodity-backed token as collateral. We face the worst of Counterparty Risk, Credit Risk, Legal Risk, Political Risk and lack of any transparent mechanism to verify absolutely the ability to foreclose on a contractual claim to gold allegedly held in a vault somewhere. What are the proofs of the authenticity and provenance of said gold? Market confidence in the representational value of such a product is too easily destroyed for this to be an attractive collateral type in my view.]  I discuss additional risk factors for the community to consider here [Signal Request] Onboard PAXG - #30 by ACREinvest  I have not been able to locate on the Forum or on the Paxos website the specific PAXG product terms and conditions. For our community Due Diligence purposes we should also have (or have access to view) copies of contracts and counterparty agreements that confirm and detail the third party commercial arrangements as described in the initial proposal (brought forward to the current date).   Given the physical nature of the gold markets and structure backing PAXG, we need to carefully verify marketing descriptions and also understand the interpretation of fine print. For example, Force Majeure is defined to include such broadly described and regularly occurring events as “cryptoasset market collapse or fluctuations.”   How might sanctions/AML/KYC requirements limit the ability of a party to convert PAXG to gold?   [Signal Request] Onboard D3M For Notional Finance  Voted NO - Requests for important additional information in the linked comment below about the specific economic arrangement and commercial ties between the Recognized Delegate proposer and counterparty Notional Finance were ignored and not provided in the Forums and not addressed in the community call. [Signal Request] Onboard D3M For Notional Finance - #20 by MadShills Founder of Notional had an extremely poor response to my questions about the company’s internal analysis of its and its products’ regulatory status and enforcement risk. I communicated my intention to vote No in this comment for the reasons stated [Signal Request] Onboard D3M For Notional Finance - #25 by ACREinvest My views on the topic Expectations of a Delegate as pertaining to the ACREinvest Delegate Platform are discussed in this thread Expectations of a delegate - #5 by ACREinvest . I fully embrace the reality that others will have different views about how to engage with the community around these issues, and believe that a diversity of approaches is important and healthy. That said, my own values on this topic will influence my vote when I detect Conflicts of Interest and potential Abuses of Power that in my opinion could harm the culture and trust bonds of MakerDAO, not to mention leave us worse off than if specific conflicts are avoided or appropriate detailed disclosures are made for the community to make an informed vote.  Judicial Approach  Without there being an explicit mandate from the community for Delegates to operate in this mode, ACREinvest views the delegate role more in the vein of a Judiciary actor. Accordingly, from my perspective initiating proposals would not be appropriate especially if the proposal includes a paid role for the Delegate or an affiliate to provide other services to the DAO. Dispassionate neutrality across the entire scope of matters before the DAO is what I’m striving for!   At this nascent stage of DeFi it is probably impossible and even undesirable to have a black-and-white, or rigidly proscribed conflicts policy. However, I do think now is a good time to elevate a discussion about Separation of Powers, and in any case set forth some daylight standards for proposals where a Conflict of Interest has been disclosed.   [Signal Request] bring back the MKR burn Part II  Voted NO [Signal Request] bring back the MKR burn Part II - #29 by ACREinvest  …purely on the merits of what is best for the protocol right now as we find the world today. I am against the burn. The fact that the change was implemented as a solution to an emergency has no bearing whatsoever on whether it is appropriate to maintain even though the urgent moment is past. November 2021 is gone. We must stay on our toes and forward looking. This shows the strength and credibility of our governance process!   [Signal Request] Real World Asset Fast-Tracking  Voted NO rather emphatically. [Signal Request] Real World Asset Fast-Tracking - #6 by ACREinvest  No, no, absolutely not. What is going on here? A “fast-track” process makes no sense at all. An ill considered, “temporary” process snatches defeat from the jaws of victory. @williamr is not at all overstating his case. Co-sign.   [Signal Request] Allocate 20M to protocol owned Uniswap V2 MKR/DAI LP  Voted NO  - [Signal Request] Allocate 20M to protocol owned Uniswap V2 MKR/DAI LP - #34 by ACREinvest  We need the surplus buffer to go higher! Also, I sense a general theme across the community of frustration with the friction and patience required to implement long-term solutions. Every attempt to grab “low-hanging fruit” or do quick “temporary” measures dilutes our focus and the potency we need as a community to navigate this massive decentralized ship.
